{{featured article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} [[File:Kalakaua, reprinted by E. Linde (ca. 1881).jpg|thumb|King Kalākaua]] The 1881 world tour of King [[Kalākaua]] of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] was his attempt to save the [[Culture of the Native Hawaiians|Hawaiian culture]] and population from extinction by importing a labor force from [[Asia-Pacific]] nations. His efforts brought the small island nation to the attention of world leaders, but sparked rumors that the kingdom was for sale. Critics in Hawaii believed the labor negotiations were just an excuse to see the world. The 281-day trip gave Kalākaua the distinction of being the first monarch to [[circumnavigation|circumnavigate]] the globe; his 1874 travels had made him the first reigning monarch to visit America and the first honoree of a [[State dinner#United States|state dinner]] at the [[White House]].
Kalākaua met with heads of state in Asia, the Mideast and Europe, to encourage an influx of [[Sugar plantations in Hawaii|sugar plantation]] labor in family groups, as well as unmarried women as potential brides for Hawaii's existing contract laborers. While in Asia, he tried to forestall American ambitions by offering a plan to [[Emperor Meiji]] for putting Hawaii under the protection of the [[Empire of Japan]] with an arranged marriage between his niece [[Kaʻiulani]] and a Japanese prince. On his visit to [[Kingdom of Portugal|Portugal]], he negotiated a treaty of friendship and commerce with Hawaii that would provide a legal framework for the emigration of Portuguese laborers to Hawaii. The King had an audience in Rome with [[Pope Leo XIII]] and met with many of the crowned heads of Europe. Britain's [[Queen Victoria]] and the splendor of her royal life impressed him more than any other monarchy; having been greatly affected by the ornate trappings of European sovereigns, he would soon have Hawaii's monarchy mirror that grandeur.
The King traveled with no security guards; only a small group of personal friends made the journey with him. Except for land transportation in cities, and two loaned ships in China and the US, his modes of transportation were seldom reserved exclusively for him. He shared regularly scheduled steamships and rail transport with fare-paying passengers. On the [[Red Sea]], he played cards and danced with other passengers. Like other tourists, he visited the [[White elephant (animal)#Thailand|white elephants of Siam]], the [[Giza pyramid complex]] in Egypt, tourist sites in India, and museums in Europe. Along the way, he exceeded his original budget, shopping regardless, and sent letters back home.
President [[James A. Garfield]] died four days before they arrived back in the United States, and Kalākaua paid a courtesy call to newly inaugurated President [[Chester A. Arthur]] at the White House in [[Washington, D.C.]] There were no public or private appearances for the King in New York, only a day at [[Coney Island]]. Before leaving the eastern US, the King met with [[Thomas Edison]] to see a demonstration of electric lights, and visited Virginia's [[Fort Monroe]]. He toured [[Hampton University|Hampton Normal and Agricultural School]], and shopped for [[Equine industry in Kentucky|horses in Kentucky]]. The royal party boarded a train to [[California]], where they were house guests of [[Claus Spreckels]] at his estate in [[Aptos, California|Aptos]] (near Santa Cruz), and spent a few days seeing the sights before sailing back to Hawaii. Kalākaua was successful in jump-starting new immigration, the first transplants arriving in Hawaii less than a year later. In the years that followed, he began emulating the lifestyles of European royalty with expensive furnishings in [[Iolani Palace]], a public coronation for himself, and a two-week public celebration of his birthday.
== Background == [[File:Kalakaua journey around the world.svg|thumb|Journey of King Kalākaua in 1881]] No other sovereign ruler had ever accomplished the feat of circling the globe, but Kalākaua, the last king of the Hawaiian Islands, had previously set other records.<ref name=WelcomeHome>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: Portugal, Spain, Scotland, England, Paris. etc.|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-10-29/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=October 29, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-10-29/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He was the first reigning monarch to visit America during his 1874 visit to Washington, D.C. for negotiations on the [[Reciprocity Treaty of 1875]]. The [[State dinner#United States|state dinner]] in his honor hosted by President [[Ulysses S. Grant]] was the first [[White House]] state dinner ever given.<ref>{{cite news|title=King Kalakaua|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1874-12-12/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=Evening Star|date=December 12, 1874|location=Washington D. C.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1874-12-12/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite web|last1=Monkman|first1=Betty C.|title=The White House State Dinner|url=https://www.whitehousehistory.org/the-white-house-state-dinner|publisher=The White House Historical Association|accessdate=December 16, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221044847/https://www.whitehousehistory.org/the-white-house-state-dinner|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> According to the personal writings of [[Queen Emma of Hawaii|Queen Dowager Emma]], a political opponent of his,{{refn|group=FN|When [[Kamehameha V]] died in 1872 without an heir, the [[1864 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii]] stipulated, in such case, that a new monarch would be elected by the [[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii|legislature]] to start a new royal line of succession. Emma and Kalākaua were political opponents in the second election following the death of the childless [[Lunalilo]], the first elected Hawaiian monarch.{{refn|{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1953|p=239}}}} Later, in her personal diary, Queen Emma described the 1881 trip as "his tour of pleasure & self-praise".{{refn|{{harvnb|Kanahele|1999|p=326}}}}}} Kalākaua supposedly had the intention in 1874 of making a world tour "for his personal gratification and vanity".<ref>{{harvnb|Kaeo|Queen Emma|1976|pages=299–302}}</ref>
The islands were officially the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] but had generally been known as the Sandwich Islands since the 1778 visit of Captain [[James Cook]]. The estimated population of [[Native Hawaiians]] when Cook arrived was 800,000. With the [[Whaling in the United States#Expansion|arrival of whaling ships]] and missionaries in the early 19th century, the Native Hawaiians were exposed to diseases for which they had no immunity and began dying in large numbers. The official 1878 census showed only 44,088 individuals who claimed Hawaiian ethnicity.<ref>{{harvnb|McDermott|Andrade|2011|pp=5–6}}</ref><ref name=Thrum1881>{{harvnb|Thrum|1881|p=10}}</ref> The sugar plantation work force in the islands and the dwindling population of the Hawaiian race had been Kalākaua's ongoing concerns. On December 24, 1880, he signed an act of the [[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii|legislative assembly]] acknowledging corruption in the immigration system and authorizing Minister of the Interior [[Henry A. P. Carter]] to take charge of licensing immigration brokers.<ref>{{cite news|title=By Authority|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-08/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=January 8, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013132725/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-08/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=October 13, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Immediately following the signing of the legislation, he visited each major island in the kingdom for a personal look at how the reciprocity treaty had affected his people. In a speech before an audience of Native Hawaiians at a Congregational church on Kauai, Kalākaua related his concerns, "I will speak to you of one of our great questions, which is the supply of people, not only to meet the requirements of all our industries but to assist in the increase of a Hawaiian population."<ref name=Kauai>{{cite news|title=His Majesty on Kauai|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-08/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=January 8, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013132723/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-08/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=October 13, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He wanted to bring in immigrants from [[Asia-Pacific]] nations, as well as Europe and the United States, to save the declining population of the Hawaiian race from completely dying out.<ref>{{cite news|title=Welcome Home|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20147643/kalakaua_welcome_home/|accessdate=May 17, 2018|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser at Newspapers.com|date=October 29, 1881}}{{free access}}</ref><ref name=WelcomeHome/> Prior labor immigration had been mostly unmarried men, and he hoped to attract unmarried women as potential wives for them, as well as bringing in family groups.<ref name=Kauai/>
{{multiple image | footer = [[Charles Hastings Judd]] and [[William Nevins Armstrong]] | align = right | image1 = Charles H. Judd.jpg | width1 = 155 | image2 = William N. Armstrong.jpg | width2 = 160 }} Kalākaua appointed [[William Nevins Armstrong]] as Attorney General in December. Armstrong had been born to Presbyterian missionaries Clarissa and [[Richard Armstrong (Hawaii)|Richard Armstrong]] in [[Lahaina, Hawaii|Lahaina]]. He had known Kalākaua since their early days at the [[Chiefs Children's School]] on Maui where he and classmate [[Charles Hastings Judd]] became friends with the future king.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|p=9}}</ref> He graduated from [[Yale University]] and became a successful lawyer before returning to Hawaii.<ref>{{harvnb|Yale University|1905|pp=567–568}}; {{cite news|title=City Directory: The Cabinet|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1880-12-04/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=December 4, 1880|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215537/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1880-12-04/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Judd had been on Kalākaua's staff since he was elected king, soon after becoming part of his Privy Council, as well as being his chamberlain and private secretary.<ref>{{cite book|editor-last=Nellist|editor-first=George F.|chapter=Charles Hastings Judd, Counselor to Royalty|title=The Story of Hawaii and Its Builders|year=1925|publisher=Honolulu Star Bulletin|location=Honolulu|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/hi/statewide/bios/judd37bs.txt|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302075318/http://files.usgwarchives.net/hi/statewide/bios/judd37bs.txt|archivedate=March 2, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Years later Armstrong remembered the invitation to join the tour as having arisen in a casual conversation, during which he did not believe the King was serious.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pp=1–2}}</ref> He realized the proposed tour was not just idle conversation when the King informed his Cabinet of his plans and chose Armstrong, Judd, and his personal cook Robert von Oelhoffen as his only traveling companions.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|p=3}}</ref> At a state dinner held by Kalākaua and his ministers a week before departure, Armstrong spoke of their youthful dreams of sailing around the world finally being brought to fruition.<ref>{{cite news|title=State Dinner|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-15/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=January 15, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230061650/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-15/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Minister of the Interior Carter issued a Bureau of Immigration Ordinance on January 14, 1881, stipulating the terms and conditions under which new immigrants would be allowed into the islands.<ref name=PCAJan22>{{cite news|title=Bureau of Immigration Ordinance – The Departure of His Majesty|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-22/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 29, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=January 22, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230060123/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-01-22/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On January 17, Kalākaua appointed Armstrong as Royal Commissioner of Immigration; Carter became acting Attorney General until their return.<ref>{{cite news|title=Island Locals|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1881-01-19/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Hawaiian Gazette|date=January 19, 1881|location=Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230061702/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1881-01-19/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Proclamation|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-02-05/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=February 5, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229233032/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-02-05/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=December 29, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Armstrong had instructions to return with a feasibility study indicating which nations were likely to provide "a desirable population"<ref name=AReport/> for the Hawaiian labor force.<ref name=AReport>{{cite news|title=Report of His Excellency W. N. Armstrong, His Hawaiian Majesty's Commissioner of Immigration, To His Excellency H. A. P. Carter|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-12-17/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=December 17, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|issue=Supplement|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229233030/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-12-17/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=December 29, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[William Lowthian Green|William L. Green]], [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Hawaii)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]], followed up with a [[communique]] to Hawaii's consulates stating the goals for the tour.<ref>{{harvnb|Char|1976|pp=95–96}}</ref>
Kalākaua's sister and heir-apparent [[Liliʻuokalani]] was to act as Regent during his absence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Proclamation|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-02-12/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=February 12, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-02-12/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She devoted a chapter of her 1898 book ''Hawaii's Story'' to her brother's tour. Her assertion was that the "[[Reform Party of Hawaii|missionary party]]" tried to exert its control by insisting that she only be allowed to be in charge of a temporary council and that all decisions in the King's absence were to be made by the entire council. She balked at the suggestion and demanded that her regency have full royal power; he agreed.<ref>{{harvnb|Liliʻuokalani|1898|pp=75–76}}</ref>
Farewell receptions were held for the King by the Catholic and Protestant communities in Honolulu on the eve of his departure. [[John Mākini Kapena]], a member of the [[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii#House of Nobles|House of Nobles]], spoke to the assembled well-wishers gathered at [[Kawaiahaʻo Church]], stating "… The great nations now look with respect on this little Kingdom and will have still more, when they see our King traveling among them for information to benefit his people, Let us all pray every day for the King's health, and safe return to his people." Throughout the night, his subjects serenaded him with traditional ''oli'' (chants) and ''mele'' (songs) outside the palace.<ref>{{harvnb|Pacific Commercial Advertiser|1881|pages=9–17}}</ref>
Kalākaua's [[Freemasonry|Masonic]] ties as Master of [[Lodge Le Progres de L'Oceanie]] would give him a global brotherhood in his travels.<ref>{{harvnb|Karpiel|2000|pp=381–389}}</ref> He and his chosen companions boarded the steamship ''City of Sydney'' at 6:30 a.m., January 20, bound for San Francisco. As the King made his way onto the ship, many in the crowd at the dock reached out to touch him.<ref name=PCAJan22/> Major [[George W. Macfarlane]], his [[aide-de-camp]], would accompany them as far as California. The King traveled as [[Aliʻi]] Kalākaua and as Prince Kalākaua, rather than in his capacity as head of state. The intent was to give the impression of a personal vacation, thereby avoiding the large costly [[retinue]] required for official business. The [[Royal Hawaiian Band]], the Hawaiian army, and a large contingent of well-wishers bid them farewell as the ''City of Sydney'' sailed out.<ref>{{cite news|title=Saturday Press|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014681/1881-01-22/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Saturday Press|date=January 22, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaii|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014681/1881-01-22/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=Feb26/>
== California, January 29 – February 8 == The ''City of Sydney'' arrived at [[San Francisco]] during a rain storm a week later, and Kalākaua's party ensconced themselves in the [[Palace Hotel, San Francisco|Palace Hotel]].<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|p=14}}</ref> Spectators amassed at the train station for their arrival in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] that week, during which the royal group visited the [[California State Legislature]]. They were accompanied in California's capital by Governor [[George Clement Perkins]], sugar baron [[Claus Spreckels]], and water engineer [[Hermann Schussler]], who had worked on several projects in Hawaii.<ref name=Feb26>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Around the World|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-02-26/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=February 26, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170623215939/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-02-26/ed-1/seq-3|archivedate=June 23, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
During the week, the King and Judd were made honorary members of the Pacific Yacht Club in [[Sausalito, California|Sausalito]] at a reception hosted by Commodore R. S. Floyd. Kalākaua was also feted at a gala in [[Chinatown, San Francisco|San Francisco's Chinatown]], given by the Chinese Consul-General and attended by leaders of the local Chinese community. It was Armstrong who delivered the after-dinner speech and offered a toast to continued good relations with the Chinese population in Hawaii.<ref name=Feb26/>
In response to Kalākaua's expressed fondness for music and the company of women, "The Ladies of the Palace Hotel" threw a formal-attire grand ball in his honor. A news commentary on the California visit stated, "…  it may be said that every hour of King Kalākaua's stay in San Francisco has been filled up with a grand ovation of activities."<ref name=Feb26/>
== Asia: March 4 – June 7 ==
=== Japan: March 4–18 === [[File:Kalakaua in Japan (1881, detail).jpg|thumb|left|Col. Charles Hastings Judd, Jugai Tokuno Riyosaki, and William N. Armstrong, [[Prince Komatsu Akihito|Prince Yoshiaki]], King Kalakaua, and Yoshie Sano Tsunetani in Japan (1881)]]
The party sailed on the ''Oceanic'' out of San Francisco on February 8. Reaching the [[Empire of Japan]] on March 4, they were surprised by elaborate welcoming ceremonies that included the playing of the anthem Kalākaua had written, "[[Hawaiʻi Ponoʻī]]". They had not given advance notice to the Japanese government of their pending visit, but the government had been alerted by a telegraph from the Imperial General Consul in San Francisco.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|p=31}}</ref> Believing a formal reception was required by their 1871 treaty with the Kingdom of Hawaii, they welcomed the King as a friendly head of state. In deference, Kalākaua acquiesced to his being treated as if he were on an official state visit.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hawaiian Kingdom Treaty of Japan 1871|url=http://hawaiiankingdom.org/treaty_japan1871.shtml|website=The Hawaiian Kingdom|publisher=Dr. David Keanu Sai|accessdate=December 16, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160323044621/http://hawaiiankingdom.org/treaty_japan1871.shtml|archivedate=March 23, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The King and his small group spent just under three weeks on their tour of Japan. They were formally welcomed at the [[Tokyo Imperial Palace]] and taken to [[Morita-za|Shintomiza, the Imperial Theatre]], to be entertained by a [[kabuki]] drama. The following day [[Emperor Meiji]] held a state dinner for his visitors. The Emperor presented the King with two suits of [[Japanese armour|Japanese armor]], and bestowed upon him the [[Order of the Chrysanthemum]] with Badge, and the Star of the Order. The King reciprocated with a royal painting of [[Queen Kapiolani]] and himself, and presented the Emperor with the [[Royal Order of Kamehameha I (decoration)|Grand Cross of Kamehameha]]. In the same ceremony, Judd and Armstrong were given the [[Order of the Rising Sun]].<ref>{{harvnb|Marumoto|1976|p=59}};{{harvnb|Yale University|1905|pp=567–568}}; {{cite web|title=David Kalakaua|url=http://wiki.samurai-archives.com/index.php?title=David_Kalakaua|website=The Samurai Archives|publisher=SamaraiWiki|accessdate=December 16, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222155944/http://wiki.samurai-archives.com/index.php?title=David_Kalakaua|archivedate=December 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> By way of understanding local education and industries, the King toured the College of the Imperial Guard, Imperial Engineering College, and the [[Oji Paper Company]].<ref name=Tour1>{{cite news|title=EXTRA: The King's Tour Around the World|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-04-20/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=April 20, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-04-20/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Two of Japan's generals gave him a guided tour through the empire's arsenal.<ref>{{harvnb|Marumoto|1976|pp=56–57}}</ref>
Concern over a possible United States seizure of the Hawaiian Islands motivated Kalākaua to hold a secret meeting with the Emperor to bring Hawaii under the protective aegis of the Japanese empire. He proposed to unite the two nations with an arranged marriage between his 5-year-old niece [[Kaʻiulani]] and 13-year-old [[Prince Higashifushimi Yorihito]].{{refn|group=FN|Also known as Prince Fushimi Sadamaro or Prince Yamashina Sadamaro.{{refn|{{harvnb|Marumoto|1976|pp=57–58}}}}}} Historian [[Ralph Simpson Kuykendall|Ralph Kuykendall]] said the proposal was rejected both by Yorihito, upon advice of his father, and by the government of Japan.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pp=62–63}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|p=230}}</ref> The Hawaiian king also recommended that Emperor Meiji create a "Union and Federation of the Asiatic nations and sovereigns" with Japan as its head, although the Emperor politely declined this idea at a later date.<ref>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|p=229}}</ref>
Japanese newspapers cautioned about looking for an emigrating labor force in Japan, stating that their own country had large areas of available agricultural land that went untouched. A ball was planned in the king's honor by the Masonic Fraternity of Yokohama, which he bowed out of when he learned of the assassination of [[Alexander II of Russia]]. The Kalākaua group arrived in [[Kobe]] on March 18 for a sightseeing tour and lunch with the mayor. On March 22, they embarked on the steamship ''Tokio Maru'' bound for Shanghai.<ref name=Tour1/> {{Quote|text=Adieu Japan – Beautiful Japan. I felt as if I would have a continual longing to see this interesting country with its kind and hospitable inhabitants for a long long time. Aloha Nui|author=Kalākaua's diary entry<ref>{{harvnb|Marumoto|1976|p=62}}</ref>}}
=== China: March 25 – April 9 === [[File:Li Hung Chang, Around the World with a King (1904).jpg|thumb|right|upright|Li Hung Chang]]
The Chinese had been a part of Hawaii's culture since the late 18th century, when the islands were first visited by Chinese merchants and tradesmen. In 1852, sugar plantations began recruiting unskilled labor from China. Because these men initially intended to return to China upon the completion of their contracts, most came without families.<ref>{{harvnb|McDermott|Andrade|2011|pp=59–80}}</ref>
Upon arriving in [[Shanghai]] on March 25, Kalākaua spent two days in residence at the [[Astor House Hotel (Shanghai)|Astor House Hotel]], receiving foreign diplomats. They departed for [[Tianjin|Tientsin]] on March 27 when [[Viceroy of Zhili|Viceroy]] [[Li Hongzhang|Li Hung Chang]] offered the steamship ''Pautah'' for their use.<ref name=LastDays>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Around the World: Last Days in Japan|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-06-11/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=June 11, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-06-11/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Kalākaua met with the Viceroy on March 31 to propose the emigration of unmarried Chinese women, as well as Chinese family units to Hawaii, to counterbalance the labor population of unmarried Chinese men. The Viceroy responded favorably and agreed to co-sponsor such an emigration with the Hawaiian government. Li arranged several events to provide Kalākaua the opportunity to meet the city's influential persons. A copy of a draft of a proposed treaty was forwarded to Hawaii's Minister of Foreign Affairs Green.<ref name=LastDays/> The ''Hong Kong Daily News'' held a positive view of Hawaii's treatment of existing Chinese laborers, but stated that the Chinese government needed to provide financial assistance for family emigration to Hawaii. The royal party returned to Shanghai on April 6. A proposed trip to [[Beijing]] was aborted when [[Empress Dowager Ci'an]] died on April 8. They sailed out of China the next day.<ref name=LastDays/><ref>{{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|p=79}}</ref>
=== Hong Kong: April 12–21 === The traveling group departed on the steamship ''Thibet'' for [[British Hong Kong]], arriving April 12. Kalākaua was the guest of Hong Kong's governor [[John Pope Hennessy]] at [[Government House, Hong Kong|Government House]], where the king was honored with a diplomatic reception and banquet. Armstrong delivered the after-dinner speech.<ref>{{cite news|title=Speech of W. N. Armstrong|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-07-09/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 18, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=July 9, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161029193717/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-07-09/ed-1/seq-3|archivedate=October 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Kalākaua was given celebratory receptions at the Victoria Lodge of Freemasons No. 1026 and Perseverance Lodge No. 1165, both in Hong Kong. Judd was voted into the masonry brotherhood at the latter, Lodge No. 1165.<ref>{{cite news|title=King Kalakaua with the Masons in Hong Kong|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-07-16/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=December 23, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=July 18, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415224224/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-07-16/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=April 15, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
They left Hong Kong on the steamship ''Killarney'' on April 21.<ref name=Latest>{{cite news|title=Latest From the King|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-06-11/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=June 11, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230061657/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-06-11/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Siam (Thailand): April 26–30 === The steamship ''Killarney'' arrived in [[Bangkok]] on April 26.<ref name=Latest/> How they would be received was speculative, since Hawaii had no treaty with Siam. Upon arrival, they were carried aboard a royal yacht up the [[Chao Phraya River|Menam River]] to Bangkok. From there, they were carried on silk chairs to one of the many [[List of palaces in Bangkok|palaces in Bangkok]] for the duration of their visit. The following day they met with King [[Chulalongkorn]] who told Kalākaua that the Siamese and Native Hawaiians were related by the common Malayan bloodline.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pp=126–127}}</ref> A member of the Siamese royal family escorted Kalākaua to see the nation's famed [[white elephant (animal)|white elephants]].<ref name=Siam>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: The King in Siam|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-07-02/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=July 2, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands}}</ref>
Chulalongkorn hosted a state dinner and made Kalākaua a Knight of the [[Order of the Crown of Thailand|Grand Cross of the Crown of Siam]]; Kalākaua reciprocated with the Royal Order of Kamehameha I. Armstrong and Judd were given the Knight Grand Cross of the Crown of Siam, Third Class.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|p=132}}; {{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|p=84}}</ref> No labor negotiations took place, although Kalākaua later mentioned in his letter to his brother-in-law Oahu Governor [[John Owen Dominis]] that "an exchange of decorations" with leaders in Asian nations potentially opened doors for future talks on immigration. He included a lengthy list of decorations to be sent to various members of the Siamese nobility.<ref>{{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|pp=82–84}}</ref>
Kalākaua's party embarked on the steamship ''Bangkok'' for Singapore on May 1. As the ship sailed away, they were bid farewell by a military gun salute, and shouts of approval by well-wishers at the dock.<ref name=Singapore>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: Arrival of His Majesty at Singapore|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-07-16/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=July 16, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-07-16/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Singapore, Malaysia, Burma (Myanmar): May 6–24 === [[File:Maharaja of Johore (PP-73-3-020).jpg|thumb|[[Abu Bakar of Johor|Abu Bakar, Maharaja of Johor]]]] By the time the ''Bangkok'' docked in [[Singapore]] on May 6, Kalākaua had had enough of formal events, turning down the offer of accommodations at [[Istana (Singapore)|Government House]] in favor of the simplicity of a hotel. Nevertheless, Governor [[Frederick Weld]] held a formal reception and state dinner for him.<ref name=Singapore/>
When he visited Sultan [[Abu Bakar of Johor]] on May 10 at the [[Istana Besar|Palace of Istana Besar]], 40 miles from Singapore, he was greeted as a brother. They squared off in the Sultan's palace over a [[billiard table]].<ref name=Singapore/> Armstrong was advised by Abu Bakar that while the inhabitants of Singapore and the Malay peninsula were good at varied professions, agricultural labor was not one of them. Abu Bakar told Armstrong that the Malay states were importing plantation labor from China and India.<ref name=AReport/>
Kalākaua and Judd visited the Lodge Zetland in the East, No. 548, in Singapore on May 11, where Judd was bestowed with the third degree in masonry.<ref name=Singapore/> The king had hoped to buy pearls for his wife Queen Kapiolani in Singapore, but found the prices prohibitive.<ref name="Kalakaua 1971 90">{{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|p=90}}</ref> On May 12, the royal entourage departed on the steamship ''Mecca''.<ref name=Singapore/>
[[Malacca]] was a six-hour layover on May 13, affording limited sightseeing. Kalākaua was given walking canes as souvenirs. Their one day at [[Penang]] on May 15 saw a visit by Governor [[John Frederick Adolphus McNair]] who hosted them at his residence of [[Suffolk House, Penang|Suffolk House]].<ref name=Indiaetc>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: Malacca, Penang, Moulmein, Rangoon, Calcutta, Bombay, Aden|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-08-06/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=August 6, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170623215944/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-08-06/ed-1/seq-1|archivedate=June 23, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A change of transportation at [[Mawlamyine|Moulmein]] put them on the steamship ''Pembo'' (or ''Pamba''), arriving in [[Yangon|Rangoon]] on May 22. During their stopover, they were entertained at Government House by the English Commissioner, and Kalākaua attended worship services at the chapel of St. John's College. They departed on May 24.<ref name=Indiaetc/>
=== India: May 28 – June 7 === Several plantation owners in Hawaii favored the importation of [[coolie]] labor from the [[East India]] region.{{refn|group=FN|States and territories of East India in 1881: [[Bihar]], [[Jharkhand]], [[Odisha]], [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]]}} Henry A. P. Carter and British consul [[James Hay Wodehouse]] had already visited England in 1879 to open a door for the process. They were discouraged by stipulations that Hawaii would be forced to pass legislation that would in essence be a detailed labor contract. There was a further requirement that such a Hawaiian law could not be changed without the approval of the governments of both Great Britain and East India. The prospect was explored through the end of 1880, when Hawaii's immigration board decided the islands could not import Indian labor within the parameters required.<ref>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pp=128–130}}</ref>
According to a report of the trip Armstrong later filed with the Hawaiian government, any negotiations for Indian contract labor had to be done with the British government in London, so no talks were conducted during their time in India.<ref name=AReport/> They arrived in [[Calcutta]] on May 28 and visited the [[Alipore Zoological Gardens]]. Kalākaua spent one day sitting in the Calcutta courthouse to observe India's legal process. Their trip across the [[British Raj|British India]] subcontinent was a sightseeing excursion during their last days before sailing to the [[Middle East]], and they stopped to tour the [[Ellora Caves]] prior to reaching [[Mumbai|Bombay]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ellora Caves|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/243|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=December 16, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161209142802/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/243|archivedate=December 9, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The King soon tired of the long journey, and was bored and restless by the time they arrived at Bombay, where they remained until the departure of their steamship on June 7. There was more in Bombay to interest him: a shopping trip, the Arab Stallion Stables, the [[Parsi]] [[Tower of Silence|Towers of Silence]], and a visit from businessman [[Sir Jamsetjee Jejeebhoy, 3rd Baronet|Sir Jamsetjee Jejeebhoy]].<ref name=Indiaetc/>
== Egypt: June 20–25 == The steamship ''Rosetta'' sailed out of Bombay on June 7, carrying Kalākaua and his friends to [[Aden]] for an afternoon of shopping on June 14, and then onto the [[Red Sea]]. In a letter to Liliʻuokalani, Kalākaua described how his romantic boyhood dreams of sailing the Red Sea were dashed by the tedium of a week on the water with no land in sight. All was not lost, since he and the estimated 70 other passengers passed the week playing games and dancing.<ref>{{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|pp=87–88}}</ref>
Arriving at the [[Suez]] on June 20, they boarded a train for [[Cairo]]. With no existing treaty with Egypt, they were pleasantly surprised by [[Khedive]] [[Tewfik Pasha]]'s offer of his Cairo palace during their stay, accommodating them with a tour of the [[Giza pyramid complex|Pyramid complex]] and the [[Great Sphinx of Giza|Great Sphinx]] on the [[Giza Plateau]].<ref>{{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|p=91}}; {{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pp=175, 181}}</ref>
Writing to his sister Liliʻuokalani from Cairo, he responded to her letter apprising him of the [[smallpox]] epidemic in the islands: "… what is the use of praying after 293 lives of our poor people have gone to their everlasting place. Is it to thank him for killing or is it to thank him for sending them to him or to the other place … To save the life of the people is to work and not pray."<ref name="Kalakaua 1971 90"/>
The ''Egyptian Gazette'' published Kalākaua's acceptance speech when the Grand Lodge of Egypt freemasons made him Honorary Grand Master of the Great Orient of Egypt.<ref>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|p=232}}</ref> He was honored with a state ball in [[Alexandria]] by the Khedive on June 24, the day before they left on the steamer ''Asia''.<ref name=Egypt>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: In Egypt-Italy-Paris-London|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-08-13/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=August 13, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215537/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-08-13/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=Naples/>
== Europe: June 29 – September 13 == Throughout their European stops, Armstrong saw a willingness among some who were looking for a life change to consider emigrating to Hawaii as plantation labor. Generally, however, they were looking for a stake in land ownership that the kingdom was not willing to offer.<ref name=AReport/>
=== Italy: June 29 – July 4 === Armstrong mentioned a brief stop at [[Catania]], on the island of [[Sicily]], probably on June 29, visiting the [[Catania Cathedral]] and [[Mount Etna]].{{refn|group=FN|No other source has mentioned this, and Armstrong did not specify a date. In his letters home, Kalākaua never mentioned Sicily, although he says they arrived in [[Naples]] at 11 a.m. on June 30. According to the [[Rick Steves]]' Europe website, a current-day ferry ride between [[Catania]] and Naples is a 12-hour trip, so the sightseeing on Catania had to have been the previous day.{{refn|{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pp=196–197}}}}{{refn|{{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|p=91}}}}{{refn|{{cite web|title=Booking a Ferry Between Naples and Catania|url=https://community.ricksteves.com/travel-forum/italy/booking-a-ferry-between-naples-and-catania#bottom|website=Rick Steves' Europe|publisher=Rick Steves' Europe, Inc.|accessdate=January 10, 2017}}}}}} Their next stop was at [[Naples]] on June 30,<ref name=Europe/> where they were greeted by the Prefect of Naples, the Commanding General and Admiral of Naples, and [[Celso Caesar Moreno]], presenting himself to local officials as the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Hawaii. Moreno was a friend of Kalākaua's who many felt was a [[confidence scam|con artist]]. Armstrong described him as someone who scammed his way into Kalākaua's good graces in Hawaii.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pp=198–199}}</ref> Moreno had been appointed Hawaii's Minister of Foreign Affairs in 1880. He created a divisive situation that put the King at odds with his own cabinet, leading to Moreno's dismissal five days later. He and Kalākaua remained on cordial terms. Moreno had been appointed the guardian of three Hawaiian students, including the future rebel leaders [[Robert Napuʻuako Boyd]] and [[Robert William Wilcox]], who were being educated in Italy as a part of the government funded study-abroad program. Moreno was relieved of that responsibility once the King was made aware that Moreno had misrepresented them as Kalākaua's natural sons, and that he had misled the Italian government into believing he had an official position with the Hawaiian government.<ref>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pp=205–222, 232}}; {{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|pp=80, 90–92}}; {{harvnb|Quigg|1988|pages=176–177}}</ref> The ''Saturday Press'' in Honolulu was indignant at his association with Kalākaua and their re-connection in Italy, stating that Moreno "… had fought to the last ditch, and has, we hope, tumbled into it and will remain there."<ref name=Naples>{{cite news|title=C. C. MORENO|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014681/1881-08-13/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=Saturday Press|date=August 13, 1881|location=Honolulu, H. I.}}</ref>
The royal group spent two hours at [[Naples National Archaeological Museum]] before having an audience with King [[Umberto I of Italy|Umberto I]] and Queen [[Margherita of Savoy|Margherita]]. They spent the next day seeing more attractions in Naples, before heading for Rome on the afternoon train.<ref name=Europe>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: Royal Diary in Europe|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-09-03/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=September 3, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116215538/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-09-03/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=January 16, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Prior to their departure, they had learned of the July 2 shooting of President [[James A. Garfield]] in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pp=205–206}}</ref>
Their time in [[Rome]] was a brief two days, during which Kalākaua, Armstrong, and Judd were granted an audience with [[Pope Leo XIII]] on July 3. After receiving his blessing, they toured [[St. Peter's Basilica]] and other local tourist sites, and left the following day by train.<ref name=Europe/> The party traveled across France and Paris without informing the French authorities, which was seen as a breach of official protocol and had to be explained at a later date.<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pages=212–213}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|page=233}}</ref>
=== England: July 6–24 === [[File:Kalakaua at Normalhurst (PP-96-13-006).jpg|thumb|300px|[[Thomas Brassey, 1st Earl Brassey|Lord Brassey]] and his wife entertaining Kalākaua and Judd at their home at [[Hastings]].]] The Kalākaua group arrived in [[London]] the evening of July 6. The King spent the next day receiving visitors in his suite at [[Claridge's]], later accepting [[Queen Victoria]]'s offer of the royal box at the [[Royal Opera House]], [[Covent Garden]]. While in England, he attended an [[Eton v Harrow]] [[cricket]] match, and returned to the Royal Opera House to hear opera singer [[Adelina Patti]].<ref name=Egypt/> The Queen's annual [[Windsor Great Park]] review of 50,000 military volunteers drew many high-ranking and titled spectators, including Kalākaua.<ref name=PallMall>{{cite journal|title=Home News|journal=[[Pall Mall Budget]]|date=April 1 – September 30, 1881|volume=26|page=28|url=https://books.google.com/?id=3Lg_AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA14-PA28&dq=queen+victoria+windsor+castle+%22volunteer+review%22#v=onepage&q=queen%20victoria%20windsor%20castle%20%22volunteer%20review%22&f=false|accessdate=December 16, 2016|location=London}}</ref> Following the review, he was entertained by [[Civil Lord of the Admiralty]] [[Thomas Brassey, 1st Earl Brassey|Thomas Brassey]] and his wife at their encampment.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=24976|date=May 24, 1881|page=2674}}; {{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|pp=94, 100}}</ref> He attended worship services at [[Westminster Abbey]] on Sunday, prior to his afternoon sailing trip with [[Lord Charles Beresford]] and guests.<ref name=Egypt/>
Kalākaua, Armstrong and Judd were formally presented to Queen Victoria at [[Windsor Castle]].<ref name=Egypt/> Kalākaua's letter to his sister Liliʻuokalani expressed his excitement about meeting the Queen, "… I was quite electrified and monopolized the whole conversation that took place during the interview."<ref name=KK9397/> His letter was effusive in details about the titled royals and aristocrats they had met, including the [[Edward VII|Prince]] and [[Alexandra of Denmark|Princess of Wales]], and the [[Frederick III, German Emperor|Crown Prince]] and [[Victoria, Princess Royal|Crown Princess of Prussia]]. The Prince of Wales paid many attentions to Kalākaua, hoping to sway him away from the United States. He insisted on giving Kalākaua precedence ahead of his brother-in-law, the [[Frederick III, German Emperor|Crown Prince of Germany]] and responded to German objections by saying, "Either the brute is a king or else he is an ordinary black nigger, and if he is not a king, why is he here?"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cannadine|first1=David|title=Ornamentalism: How the British Saw Their Empire|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195157949|page=8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=daDh_x2Ne_wC&pg=PA8|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428061441/https://books.google.com/books?id=daDh_x2Ne_wC&pg=PA8|archivedate=April 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Hibbert|first1=Christopher|title=Edward VII: The Last Victorian King|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9781403983770|page=147|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xv4VdYIGLAoC&pg=PA147|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051053/https://books.google.com/books?id=Xv4VdYIGLAoC&pg=PA147|archivedate=April 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Baycroft|first1=Timothy|last2=Hewitson|first2=Mark|title=What Is a Nation?: Europe 1789-1914|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=9780191516283|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VG01nx2vezoC&pg=PA326|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428063555/https://books.google.com/books?id=VG01nx2vezoC&pg=PA326|archivedate=April 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Churchwell|first1=Sarah|last2=Smith|first2=Thomas Ruys|title=Must Read: Rediscovering American Bestsellers: From Charlotte Temple to The Da Vinci Code|date=2012|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=9781441162168|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qubh7e5XW0kC&pg=PA201|language=en}}</ref> At this point in their trip, Armstrong temporarily returned to his family in the United States.<ref name=KK9397>{{harvnb|Kalakaua|1971|pp=93–97}}</ref>
Hawaii's relationship with A. Hoffnung & Company in London dated back to 1877 when Hawaii's Minister of Foreign Affairs Henry A. P. Carter recommended the firm to handle Portuguese emigration to the island kingdom.<ref>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pp=124–125, 143–44, }}</ref> The firm's founder Abraham Hoffnung was attached to the Hawaiian Board of Immigration in London, and had already succeeded in sending Hawaii 751 Portuguese citizens (237 men, 191 women, and 323 children) in 1879.<ref name=Kuykendall125>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|p=125}}</ref> Kalākaua reconnected with Hoffnung over dinner, and he became part of the royal party as it traveled through Europe.<ref name=WelcomeHome/><ref name=Egypt/><ref name=Paris/>
On July 23, the day before departing for Brussels, Kalākaua had lunch with the [[Francis, Duke of Teck|Duke of Teck]], and inspected ships at the [[Yarrow Shipbuilders]].<ref name=Europe/>
=== Belgium, Germany: July 25 – August 4 === Kalākaua and Judd left England on July 24, arriving in [[Brussels]] the next morning. They spent a few days sightseeing, and visited [[Waterloo, Belgium|Waterloo]], where [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] had been [[Battle of Waterloo|defeated in 1815]]. Kalākaua presented Belgium's [[Leopold II of Belgium|King Leopold II]] with the Order of Kamehameha when he paid a visit to him.<ref name=Brussels>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: Brussels, Berlin, Vienna|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-09-10/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=September 10, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229233012/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-09-10/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=December 29, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
They arrived at [[Cologne]] on July 29, visiting the [[Cologne Cathedral]] before continuing on to [[Berlin]]. Kalākaua stayed in his Berlin accommodations and took care of his correspondence the first full day of his stay, with German soldiers standing vigil outside his door. He received boisterous expressions of public approval wherever he appeared. During their stay, they attended several military displays and toured museums, castles, and other sites of interest. The King was entertained by the future [[Kaiser Wilhelm II]] and his wife, who were receiving him on behalf of Wilhelm's grandfather, the [[William I, German Emperor|German Emperor]]. On a visit to [[Potsdam]] with [[Prince Charles of Prussia]], Kalākaua was awarded the Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Red Eagle]]. Armstrong rejoined the group in Germany, but was too ill to accompany them on their outings. They departed for [[Vienna]] on August 4.<ref name=Brussels/><ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pages=251–254}}</ref>
=== Vienna, Austria: August 5–8 === Onlookers gathered at Vienna's {{Ill|Wien Nordwest railway station|de|Wien Nordwestbahnhof|WD=|lt=Northwest station}} in anticipation of Kalākaua's arrival. When he stepped off the train to be escorted by Austrian officials to the [[Hotel Imperial]], cheering rang out from the crowd. He later visited the Imperial Arsenal. After a tour of the [[Belvedere, Vienna|Belvedere]], he attended a concert conducted by [[Eduard Strauss]] at the [[Volksgarten, Vienna|Volksgarten]]. In the evening he enjoyed a ballet at the [[Vienna State Opera|Imperial Opera House]].<ref name=Vienna>{{cite news|title=The King at Vienna|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-10-01/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=October 1, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands}}</ref>
The royal family had already left Vienna for the summer,<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|p=255}}</ref> but Kalākaua got to inspect the troops during military maneuvers at the [[Schmelz (Vienna)|Schmelz]] parade grounds. He later had an audience with [[Archduke Albrecht, Duke of Teschen]]. In the evening, he returned to the opera house for a performance of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s ''[[The Marriage of Figaro]]''. The next two days were spent sightseeing, including the [[Schönbrunn Palace]], [[St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna|St. Stephen's Cathedral]], the [[Votive Church, Vienna|Votive Church]], and the ''[[Neue Freie Presse]]''.<ref name=Vienna/>
On August 8, the King and his friends took the evening train to Paris.<ref name=Vienna/>
=== Paris: August 10–15 === The Royal party arrived at the [[Gare de l'Est (Paris Métro)|Gare de l'Est]] train station in Paris in the pre-dawn hours of August 10, rejoined by Macfarlane. Most of the first day they remained in their suite, recovering from travel exhaustion. They soon ventured out to see to the [[Auteuil Hippodrome]], and stopped by various concert halls.<ref name=Paris>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: The King is in Paris|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-10-08/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=October 8, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands}}</ref>
Armstrong noted that the party was received with "the [[cold shoulder]]"<ref name=AK/> by diplomatic authorities for the first time on their trip, while the King in return considered them to be a "mean lot".<ref name=AK/> They had to apologize for the diplomatic slight from the earlier July stopover, and explain the reason why an invitation for the King, received while they were still in London, to attend the [[Bastille Day]] celebration as a guest of [[Jules Grévy|President Grévy]] was left unanswered. After the tension was smoothed out, the [[Jules Barthélemy-Saint-Hilaire|French foreign minister]] visited the King in the absence of the president who was not in the capital at that time.<ref name=AK>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pages=258–260}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|page=234}}</ref>
Otherwise, their stay in Paris was filled with well-wishers who came to call at the hotel. Queen Victoria sent her [[chargé d'affaires]] to present him with the Grand Cross of the Most Distinguished [[Order of St. Michael and St. George]]. After days of visitors, which included world dignitaries and representatives of two different Masonic lodges, Kalākaua and friends attended a performance of [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s opera ''[[Aida]]''. He was given a tour of the headquarters of ''[[Le Figaro]]'', and visited the [[Société de géographie]]. On August 15, the royal group, which now included Hoffnung, left on the evening train, bound for Portugal and Spain.<ref name=Paris/>
=== Iberian Peninsula (Portugal and Spain): August 19–25 === [[File:The King of Portugal, Around the World with a King (1904).jpg|thumb|upright|King [[Luís I of Portugal]]]] Portuguese immigrants had been in Hawaii since the whaling days. Many of them were mixed blood [[Afro-Portuguese]] sailors who found the brown-skinned Native Hawaiians free of racial bias towards them. The first Portuguese plantation labor emigration to Hawaii came from the [[Azores]] and [[Madeira]] in 1878, starved out of their homelands by widespread grape vine fungus.<ref>{{harvnb|McDermott|Andrade|2011|pp=81–106}}</ref> They emigrated mostly in family groups, joining an established community of their own culture.<ref>{{harvnb|Thrum|Marques|1886|pp=74–78}}</ref>
Armstrong's instructions for [[Kingdom of Portugal|Portugal]] were to negotiate an expanded treaty with the government.<ref name=A264>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|p=264}}</ref> They arrived at [[Santa Apolónia railway station]] in [[Lisbon]] on August 19. Kalākaua was presented with the Grand Cross [[Order of the Immaculate Conception of Vila Viçosa]] during an audience with [[Luís I of Portugal|King Luís I]] at the [[Palace of Ajuda]], and also attended a bullfight with Luis's father [[Ferdinand II of Portugal|King Ferdinand II]] at the [[Pena Palace]]. When they left Portugal on August 24, Armstrong remained behind to initiate a treaty.<ref name=A264/><ref>{{harvnb|Dias|1984|pp=74–76}}; {{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: Additional Particulars of the Royal Visit to Spain and Portugal|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-10-15/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=October 15, 1881|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands}}</ref>
The royal group toured Madrid on August 24, visiting the Royal Army, [[Museo del Prado]], and [[Buen Retiro Park]]. The Spanish minister presented Kalākaua with the [[Order of Charles III]]. An announcement was released to the newspapers that an arrangement had been made for Portugal to send 300 families to the Hawaiian Islands in the near future. They departed for Paris on August 25.<ref name=WelcomeHome/>
=== Revisiting Paris: August 27–30 === Winding down his tour, Kalākaua's schedule became less hectic. He spent most of August 27 relaxing in his hotel suite in Paris, and attending to his personal correspondence. A little sightseeing was done over the next two days: Napoleon's tomb at [[Les Invalides]], [[Bal Mabille]], the [[Louvre]], and [[Palais Bourbon]]. Dutch heir-apparent [[Alexander, Prince of Orange]], visited the King to thank him for the Grand Cross of the Order of Kalākaua. The King spent his remaining day in the city, August 30, in his hotel suite, saying his farewells.<ref name=WelcomeHome/>
=== Revisiting London: August 31 – September 6 === The train carrying Kalākaua and his travel companions arrived in London at [[Charing Cross railway station]] the morning of August 31. In the evening they all attended a performance at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane Theatre]]. Armstrong left for New York City on September 1, as the rest of the party went sightseeing and visited the tomb of [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington]] in [[St Paul's Cathedral]]. The following day they visited the [[Tower of London]], and later in the day, Kalākaua received the Holy Cross of Wasa from Sweden's chargé d'affaires. On September 3, the royal party visited the Blenheim Gun and Small Arms Works, where they lunched with several dignitaries. After services at St Paul's Cathedral, Kalākaua bestowed the [[Royal Order of Kalākaua]] on Hoffnung for his service during their travels around Europe. On September 6, he paid a farewell visit to the Prince and Princess of Wales, before departing for Glasgow, Scotland.<ref name=WelcomeHome/>
=== Scotland: September 7–13 === Kalākaua arrived in [[Glasgow]] on September 7. The [[Lord Provost of Glasgow]] and the magistrates hosted the King at a dinner party, where he gave a speech praising the contributions of Scotsmen in Hawaii. For the rest of his stay, he toured [[Loch Lomond]] and the [[River Clyde]]. Visiting [[Edinburgh]] on September 9, he toured [[Dreghorn Castle]] and [[Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh|the Royal Botanic Garden]], where he planted two maple trees. Kalākaua appeared at Freemason Hall to loud cheers. The Grand Conclave of Scotland of the Order of the Red Cross of Constantine made him an honorary member.<ref name=WelcomeHome/>
Hawaii's royal tourists departed for America via Liverpool on September 13.<ref name=WelcomeHome/>
== Across the United States: September 23 – October 22 == The steamship ''Celtic'' pulled into [[New York Harbor]] on September 23, carrying Kalākaua, Judd, Macfarlane, and von Oelhoffen. Awaiting them on the dock were Armstrong, Hawaiian consul general Elisha Hunt Allen, Jr. and Claus Spreckels.<ref>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|p=234}}</ref> New York was in mourning over the September 19 death of President Garfield. Out of respect to the solemnity of the tragedy, Kalākaua attended no public or private functions in the city.<ref name=NY924>{{cite news|title=King Kalākaua's Arrrival|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1881-09-24/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Sun|date=September 24, 1881|location=New York, NY|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230061638/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1881-09-24/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The royal party did, however, spend a day as private tourists at [[Coney Island]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Recreations of Royalty|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1881-09-25/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Sun|date=September 25, 1881|location=New York, NY|page=5|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230120608/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1881-09-25/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In Vienna during the first week in August, Kalākaua had made the acquaintance of ''[[The New York Times]]'' co-founder [[George Jones (publisher)|George Jones]], who noticed the King had an interest in [[Thomas Edison]]'s work with electric lighting. Returning to New York, Jones arranged for Kalākaua and Armstrong to visit Edison on September 25. The King expressed an urgent need for Honolulu to upgrade its street lighting, which at that time was provided by [[kerosene lamp]]s. Edison demonstrated some electric light bulbs, and Kalākaua showed interest in the technical details. ''[[The Sun (New York)|The Sun]]'' newspaper reported that Armstrong joked with Edison about generating electric power from [[List of volcanoes in the Hawaiian – Emperor seamount chain|Hawaiian volcanoes]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Kalakaua Visits Edison: The King in Search of a Means to Light Up Honolulu|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1881-09-26/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 23, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Sun|date=September 26, 1881|location=New York, NY|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161029014614/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1881-09-26/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=October 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=King Kalakaua's Movements – His Majesty Examines The Edison Electric Light|newspaper=The New York Times|location=New York|date=September 26, 1881|volume=|issue=|page=|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1881/09/26/98566988.pdf|accessdate=September 26, 2016}}</ref> They left the city by train on the following day for [[Philadelphia]], staying there for a brief rest, and then heading south to [[Washington, D. C.]]<ref>{{cite news|title=The Regal Sight-Seer – King Kalakaua Arrives In The City|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/52205934/?terms=kalakaua|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Newspaper.com|subscription=yes|publisher=The Times|date=September 27, 1881|location=Philadelphia|page=5|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227201125/https://www.newspapers.com/image/52205934/?terms=kalakaua|archivedate=December 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
[[File:20 Chester Arthur 3x4.jpg|thumb|upright|President [[Chester A. Arthur]]]] Arriving in Washington, D. C. on September 27, they stayed at the [[Arlington Hotel (Washington, D.C.)|Arlington Hotel]]. On the following day, the party was introduced by the Assistant Secretary of State [[Robert R. Hitt]] to the newly inaugurated President [[Chester A. Arthur]], at the home of Virginia Senator [[John W. Johnston]]. The informal private interview lasted only twenty minutes but was described as pleasant. Armstrong later described their similarities: "If the President had been a dark or black man, the [physical] resemblance would have been a singular one."<ref>{{harvnb|Armstrong|1904|pages=274–275}}; {{cite news|title=A Royal Visitor|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1881-09-28/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 23, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|newspaper=Evening Star|date=September 28, 1881|location=Washington, D. C.}}</ref><ref name=PCADC>{{cite news|title=The King's Tour Round the World: Washington, D. C., Fortress Monroe, and Virginia|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|accessdate=January 14, 2017|location=Honolulu|date=October 22, 1881|volume=|issue=|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1881-10-22/ed-1/seq-2/}}</ref>
After the presidential visit, the royal party headed to [[Baltimore]] where [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[William H. Hunt]] provided a governmental vessel, the [[USS Despatch (1873)|USS ''Despatch'']], to transport them to [[Tidewater Virginia]]. The King toured [[Fort Monroe|Fortress Monroe]] where General [[George W. Getty]] received him before spending the day with Armstrong's brother [[Samuel C. Armstrong|Samuel]] at [[Hampton University|Hampton Normal and Agricultural School]].<ref>{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pp=234–235}}; {{cite news|title=Washington News and Gossip|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1881-09-29/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 23, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|newspaper=Evening Star|date=September 29, 1881|location=Washington, D. C.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230120606/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1881-09-29/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Kalakaua at Fortress Monroe|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045160/1881-09-30/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 23, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|newspaper=Memphis Daily Appeal|date=September 30, 1881|location=Memphis, TN|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230114610/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045160/1881-09-30/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The King was interested in the institution's role in educating [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] in the industrial trade, a model he wanted to bring back to his people, even though Samuel Armstrong had modeled his school after the [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo]] Boarding School in Hawaii. After a visit to the Old Soldier's Home and a reception at Virginia Hall, the party returned north to Fortress Monroe, where they witnessed a review, and then proceeded to the [[Norfolk Naval Shipyard]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Rouse|first=Parke|title=Hawaiian King Reaffirmed Ties Between Islands And Hampton|newspaper=The Daily Press|location=Newport News, VA|date=May 3, 1989|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1989-05-03/news/8905030089_1_king-kalakaua-hawaiian-king-hawaiian-islands|accessdate=December 23, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227131342/http://articles.dailypress.com/1989-05-03/news/8905030089_1_king-kalakaua-hawaiian-king-hawaiian-islands|archivedate=December 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|last=Sigall|first=Bob|title=Hilo Boarding School inspired the founding of 2 prestigious mainland colleges|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|location=Newport News, VA|date=July 29, 2016|url=https://www.pressreader.com|accessdate=December 23, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20161214044911/http://www.pressreader.com/|archivedate=December 14, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It was reported that the royal party also visited [[Yorktown, Virginia|Yorktown]] to observe the centennial celebration of [[Siege of Yorktown|its siege]].<ref name=PCADC/>
Returning to the capital on October 2, they boarded a train, arriving the next day at [[Cincinnati]], where they stayed at the Grand Hotel. While Armstrong remained in Cincinnati, Kalākaua, Judd, and Macfarlane took a trip to [[Lexington, Kentucky]], visiting the city, meeting the local dignitaries, and spending a night with General William T. Withers at his home Fairlawn, outside the city. The following day they visited the [[Elmendorf Farm|Kentucky thoroughbred farm]] of [[Milton H. Sanford]], where they purchased two stallions and five mares for shipment back to Honolulu, although contradictory reports in the Louisville press stated they did not purchase any horses. Afterward they returned to Cincinnati and boarded another train heading west.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kalakaua on HIs Way Home|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/31429829/?terms=Kalakaua|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Newspaper.com|subscription=yes|publisher=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=October 5, 1881|location=Cincinnati, OH|page=5|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227200943/https://www.newspapers.com/image/31429829/?terms=Kalakaua|archivedate=December 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=King Kalakaua – How He Was Received at Lexington – Col. Judd Talks of the Sandwich Islanders – In Love With The Bluegrass|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/30726482/?terms=Kalakaua|accessdate=December 16, 2016|via=Newspaper.com|subscription=yes|publisher=The Courier Jourmal|date=October 6, 1881|location=Louisville, KT|page=2|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227200945/https://www.newspapers.com/image/30726482/?terms=Kalakaua|archivedate=December 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Midwest"/>
At a scheduled layover in [[Chicago]], they disembarked only long enough for breakfast and to answer some brief media questions before the train resumed its route.<ref name=Midwest>{{cite news|title=Washington News and Gossip|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1881-10-03/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=December 23, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|publisher=The Canton Advocate|date=October 20, 1881|location=Canton, SD|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227000108/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025440/1881-10-20/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=December 27, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In [[Omaha, Nebraska]], the King was the guest of honor at a reception held in the home of Judge James M. Woolworth. Most of the attendees were friends of the judge's daughter, who had met the King on a vacation in Hawaii. Although Kalākaua had claimed exhaustion from his world trip, he nevertheless danced the whole night with the women guests.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Reception to H. H. M. Kalakaua at Judge Woolworth's|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99021999/1881-10-10/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=December 24, 2016|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers.
