[[File:Edmund Burke by Sir Joshua Reynolds.jpg|alt=|thumb|Edmund Burke praised Christianity's ability to strengthen British society.]] The '''religious thought of Edmund Burke''' includes published works by [[Edmund Burke]] and commentary on the same. Burke's religious thought was grounded in his belief that [[religion]] is the foundation of [[civil society]].<ref>Edmund Burke, ''Reflections on the Revolution in France'' (London: J. M. Dent & Sons, 1964), 87.</ref> He sharply criticized [[deism]] and [[atheism]], and emphasized [[Christianity]] as a vehicle of [[social progress]].<ref>Ian Harris, “Burke and Religion,” in David Dwan and Christopher J Insole eds., ''The Cambridge Companion to Edmund Burke'' (Cambridge University Press, 2012), 103.</ref> Born in [[Ireland]] to a [[Protestant]] father and [[Catholic]] mother, Burke vigorously defended the [[Church of England]] but also demonstrated sensitivity to Catholic concerns.<ref name="Ibid" /> He linked the conservation of a [[state religion]] with the preservation of citizens’ constitutional liberties and highlighted Christianity’s benefits not only to the believer’s soul but also to political arrangements.<ref name="Ibid">Harris, 98.</ref>
== Early views ==
Edmund Burke’s early essays “Religion of No Efficacy Considered as a State Engine” and “Religion” criticize contemporary efforts to reduce religion to a social and political instrument.<ref>Edmund Burke, “Religion of No efficacy considered as a State Engine” in H.V.F. Somerset ed., ''A Note-book of Edmund Burke'' (Cambridge University Press, 1957), 67</ref> “The Principle of Religion,” Burke wrote, “is that God attends to our actions to reward and punish them.” <ref>''A Note-book'', 67.</ref> Religion then, according to Burke, is ultimately something mysterious.<ref>'A Note-book'', 68.</ref> It cannot exist without a personal God who places responsibilities on his creation.<ref>Edmund Burke, “Religion” in 'A Note-book'', 70.</ref> Burke claimed that, “Moral Duties are included in Religion, and enforced by it.<ref>Edmund Burke, “Religion”</ref> Burke’s identification of religion as the source of morality is a reoccurring theme throughout his work.<ref>Harris, 92.</ref>
== Social benefits of Christianity compared with deism ==
Ian Harris has observed that Burke “emphasized the social benefits of Christianity, rather than its truth.” <ref>Harris, 103.</ref> Burke considered Christianity the source of civilization and appealed to the Christian tradition for both eternal salvation and human welfare in this life.<ref name="Harris_a">Harris, 103</ref> However, although Burke “presumed the truth of Christianity,” he did not try to explain its central doctrines.<ref name="Harris_b">Harris, 94</ref> This was consistent with Burke’s overall approach to religion, which was essentially political and philosophical rather than theological.<ref name="Harris_a" />
Burke’s view that religion is the source of morality led him to view its absence as a perilous possibility.<ref name="Reflections_a">''Reflections'', 87.</ref> His first published book, ''A Vindication of Natural Society'', satirizes the deism of his contemporary [[Viscount Bolingbroke]].<ref>Edmund Burke, “A Vindication of Natural Society,” in Isaac Kramnick ed, ''The Portable Edmund Burke'' (New York: Penguin Books, 1999), 29.</ref> Drawing a distinction between revealed religions (those that believe in divinely inspired scripture) and natural religion or deism, Burke’s pseudo-Bolingbroke argues that revealed religion and civil society are similarly peppered with evils. If the remedy to revealed religion is natural religion, than the solution to civil society is natural society.<ref>Harris, 96.</ref> By connecting natural religion with a primitive state of nature, Burke suggests the anti-social and degenerating implications of deism.<ref name="Harris_d">Harris, 96</ref> Burke considered religion and morality “sublime principles” and called for “religious establishments...that many continually revive and support them.” <ref name="Reflections_b">''Reflections'', 88.</ref> In this way, Burke envisioned Christianity as “contributing directly to the cohesion and improvement of society.” <ref name="Harris_b" /> Burke argued that “ the consecration of the state by a state religious establishment” was necessary to secure the freedom of Englishmen.<ref name="Reflections">''Reflections'', 89.</ref> Only a state sanctioned religion, according to Burke, could effectively instill citizens with a sense of awe and responsibility for their actions.<ref name="Reflections" /> A religion connected with the state was essential to making people realize that “they are to account for their conduct...to the one great Master, Author and Founder of society.” <ref name="Reflections" />
== Pluralism and toleration ==
Although Burke was a forceful defender of the Church of England, his view that a revealed religion was indispensable to a society’s progress was not limited to Christianity.<ref>Harris, 99.</ref> In a speech before the House of Commons, Burke commended the “[[Hinduism|Hindoo]] (sic) Religion” for contributing to the “flourishing” of India.<ref>Quoted in Harris, 99.</ref> Similarly, he lauded [[Islamic]] governments for having the “double sanction of law and religion.” <ref>Edmund Burke, “Speeches on the Impeachment of Warren Hastings,” in Isaac Kramnick ed, ''The Portable Edmund Burke'' (New York: Penguin Books, 1999), 397.</ref> Ian Harris cautions that these praises do not imply that Burke “entertained relativism about religious truth.” Instead, Harris argues that these statements suggest Burke believed “that the religion which has become bound up with a society is the one that suits it." <ref name="Harris">Harris, 100.</ref> Burke also spoke in support of Catholics and dissenters from the Church of England.<ref name="EdmundBurke">Edmund Burke, “Speech on Relief of Protestant Dissenters” in Louis I. Bredvold and Ralph G, Ross eds., ''The Philosophy of Edmund Burke'' (Ann Arbor: The University of Mitchigan Press, 1960), 76-77.</ref> He argued that because the church was “built up with the strong and stable matter of the gospel of liberty” it had nothing to fear from allowing other Christian groups to worship as they wished. Burke asserted that the Church of England’s “security of her own doctrines” made it possible to establish legal acceptance for Protestants and Catholics.<ref name="EdmundBurke" /> “Toleration,” Burke argued, “so far from being an attack upon Christianity, becomes the best and surest support that possibly can be given to it.” <ref name="EdmundBurke" /> However, Burke fiercely defended the Church Establishment from attacks from within the Church of England. He publicly opposed the petition of several clergymen from the Church of England who asked to be relieved from subscription to the articles of the Act of Uniformity of 1662.<ref>Edmund Burke, “Speech on the Acts of Uniformity” in Louis I. Bredvold and Ralph G, Ross eds., ''The Philosophy of Edmund Burke'' (Ann Arbor: The University of Michigan Press, 1960), 119.</ref> Burke advocated allowing English dissenters to practice Christianity the way they saw fit, but he briskly opposed efforts to subvert church authorities.<ref>Edmund Burke, “Speech on the Acts of Uniformity” in Louis I. Bredvold and Ralph G, Ross eds., The Philosophy of Edmund Burke (Ann Arbor: The University of Michigan Press, 1960), 119.</ref>
== Religion and the French Revolution ==
Burke’s criticisms of the [[French Revolution]] reiterated his longstanding view that revealed religion is an integral part of a civilized society.<ref>Harris, 100</ref> He sharply condemned the confiscation of Church property by the revolutionaries and claimed that their nonreligious views were “against, not only our reason, but our instincts.” <ref name="Reflections_b" /> Burke predicted that if France rejected Catholicism, “some uncouth, pernicious, and degrading superstition might take the place of it.”<ref name="Reflections_b" />
Harris observes that Burke discerned clear religious features in the French Revolution.<ref name="Harris_c">Harris, 102.</ref> As the Revolution turned more radical and entered its international phrase, Burke thought of it “as no mere exercise in extending French rule, but instead as a crusade to destroy Christianity in Europe.” <ref name="Harris_c" /> “In a drunken delirium,” Burke wrote, France risked “uncover[ing] our nakedness.” <ref name="Reflections_a" /> The practice of a natural religion without revelation implied retrogression to “a savage and incoherent mode of life.” <ref>Quoted in Harris, 102.</ref> Burke’s mature thought on religion reveals a remarkable consistency throughout his long career.<ref name="Harris_a" /> For Burke, the French Revolution was a vivid example of the catastrophic consequences of deism, which he had ridiculed in ''A Vindication of Natural Society'' more than thirty years before.<ref name="Harris_d" /> The inadequacy of natural religion for both personal salvation and civil society are enduring themes of Burke’s thought. Burke believed that only revealed religions, especially Christianity, offer the possibility of social and political improvement.<ref name="Harris_a" /> Linking morality and religion, Burke believed that the former could not exist without the latter. According to Burke, only institutional churches can effectively uphold these sublime principles and enable the fulfillment of man’s obligations both to his neighbors and to God.

{{small|([[Government revenue|Diploma in Revenue & Tax Management]])}} | occupation = [[Politician]] | years_active = 1999 — present | nationality = [[Uganda]]n | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] | known_for = [[Politics]] | networth = | home_town = [[Anaka]] | title = }} '''Richard Todwong''' is a [[Uganda]]n [[politician]]. He is the [[Minister Without Portfolio]] in the [[Cabinet of Uganda|Ugandan Cabinet]]. He was appointed to that position on 15 August 2012.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201208160040.html| title=Uganda: Museveni Reshuffles Cabinet|accessdate=5 October 2014| date=15 August 2012|first=Rukiya|last=Makuma|newspaper=[[The Independent (Uganda)]] (Kampala)}} He replaced [[Nasser Sebaggala]] who was appointed in May 2011, but was rejected by [[Parliament of Uganda|parliament]]. Richard Todwong is also the elected [[Parliament of Uganda|Member of Parliament]] for ''Nwoya County'', [[Nwoya District]].{{cite web|date=5 October 2014| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Is-minister-Todwong-the-new--stick--against-the-old-guard-/-/688334/2475292/-/15ky84i/-/index.html|title=Is Minister Todwong The New ‘Stick’ Against The Old Guard?|accessdate=5 October 2014| newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] (Kampala)|first=Mike|last=Ssegawa}} ==Background== He was born on 24 November 1973 in [[Anaka]], [[Nwoya District]]. ==Education== Richard Todwong holds the degree of [[Bachelor of Arts|Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences]] (B.A.Soc.Scs.), obtained from [[Makerere University]], [[Uganda]]'s oldest and largest [[public university]], His degree of [[International Relations|Master of Arts in International Relations]] (M.A.Int.Rel.) was also obtained from Makerere. His [[Management|Diploma in Management]] (Dip.Mgnt.) was obtained from the [[Uganda Management Institute]]. He also holds the postgraduate [[Government revenue|Diploma in Revenue and Tax Administration]] from the [[Uganda Revenue Authority]] (URA).{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.go.ug/new/index.php/members-of-parliament/members-of-parliament|title=Profile of Richard Todwong|date=2011|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=[[Parliament of Uganda|Parliament.go.ug]]|first=.|last=Uganda Parliament|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160527141255/http://www.parliament.go.ug/new/index.php/members-of-parliament/members-of-parliament|archivedate=27 May 2016|df=dmy-all}} ==Work experience== From 1999 until 2000, Todwong worked as a Revenue Officer at the [[Uganda Revenue Authority]], the Uganda government body responsible for tax collection. From 2000 until 2003, he served as [[Commissioner]] at the Constitutional Revenue Commission. Between 2006 and 2010, he served as a Special Advisor to the [[President of Uganda]]. In 2011, he entered elected politics by contesting for the ''Nwoya County'' Constituency in the [[Parliament of Uganda]]. He ran on the [[National Resistance Movement]] (NRM) political party ticket. He won and is the [[incumbent]]. In 2012, he was appointed [[Minister Without Portfolio]]. In 2013, he was given responsibility by he NRM political party to assist the [[Secretary General]] in mobilization activities.{{cite web| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/artsculture/Reviews/Richard-Todwong--a-man-in-the-limelight/-/691232/2250554/-/view/printVersion/-/h49xx9/-/index.html |title=Richard Todwong: A Man In The Limelight|accessdate=5 October 2014|date=2013|newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] (Kampala)|first=and Profiles|last=Reviews}} ==See also== *[[Cabinet of Uganda]] *[[Parliament of Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/1170806/-/c0y8sbz/-/index.html Full of List of Ugandan Cabinet Ministers May 2011] {{DEFAULTSORT:Todwong, Richard}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Government ministers of Uganda]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Uganda]] [[Category:People from Nwoya District]] [[Category:Acholi people]] [[Category:National Resistance Movement politicians]] [[Category:Makerere University alumni]] [[Category:Uganda Management Institute alumni]]

The '''Splat Pack''' is a collection of [[independent filmmakers]] who, since 2002, have directed, written and produced numerous R-rated [[horror film]]s, notable for their [[Low-budget film|low budgets]] and extreme ultra-violence.<ref name="the splat pack">{{cite news |title=The Splat Pack |first=Rebecca |last=Winters Keegan |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1549299,00.html |newspaper= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date= October 22, 2006|accessdate=January 7, 2011}}</ref>
==History== The term was coined by [[Alan Jones (film critic)|Alan Jones]] of ''[[Total Film]]''.<ref name="blood brothers">{{cite news |title=Blood Brothers |first=Alan |last=Jones |authorlink=Alan Jones (film critic) |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117956275.html?categoryid=13&cs=1&s=h&p=0 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=December 24, 2006 |accessdate=January 7, 2011}} </ref> The group has been credited with bringing back ultra-violent movies, as well as moving away from [[MPAA film rating system|PG-13]] rated movies and into the [[MPAA film rating system|R-rated]] spectrum, all while operating with [[independent film|low budgets]].<ref name="the splat pack"/><ref name="horrors">''New York Post''; October 22, 2006. [http://www.nypost.com/seven/10222006/entertainment/horrors__entertainment_reed_tucker.htm?page=1 Horrors!]; retrieved April 2, 2007</ref> The members have repeatedly clashed with the [[MPAA]] board over the content of their work but nevertheless continue to find substantial box-office success.<ref name="blood brothers"/><ref name="horrors"/> In 2011 a documentary on the Splat Pack was made featuring extensive interviews with members Alexandre Aja, Adam Green, Eli Roth, Darren Lynn Bousman, Neil Marshall, and Greg McLean.

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- For groups; see Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = The Balfa Brothers | image = TheBalfaBrothers1974.jpg | alt = Ray Abshire playing with The Balfa Brothers at the Festival Acadian in Lafayette - 1974 | caption = Ray Abshire playing with The Balfa Brothers at the Festival Acadian in Lafayette - 1974 | image_size = | landscape = yes | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Louisiana]], United States | label = [[Swallow Records|Swallow]] | website = | past_members = [[Dewey Balfa]], Will Balfa, Rodney Balfa, and Hadley Fontenot | genre = [[Cajun music|Cajun]] }}
'''The Balfa Brothers''' (or '''Les Frères Balfa''') were an American [[cajun music]] ensemble. Its members were five brothers; [[Dewey Balfa|Dewey]] on fiddle, Will on fiddle, Rodney on guitar, harmonica, and vocals, Burkeman on [[triangle (music)|triangle]] and spoons, and Harry on [[Cajun accordion]].
==History== The brothers first played together at family gatherings in the 1940s. Their father, Charles Balfa, a sharecropper, had played fiddle and was a singer. Along with Hadley Fontenot, an accordionist and acquaintance of the family, they made their first recordings in 1951. The [[78rpm]] single was "La Valse de Bon Baurche" b/w "Le Two Step de Ville Platte", recorded at their house. After this Dewey went on to a successful solo career, recording on his own and with many ensembles.
Adopting the name Balfa Brothers in 1967, Dewey, Rodney, Will, Hadley Fontenot, and Dewey's daughter Nelda started touring [[folk festival]]s and European venues, playing Cajun music at a time in which its impact on American music had largely been forgotten. They made their first new recordings that year, and played at the [[1968 Summer Olympics]] in [[Mexico City]].
They released several albums and appeared in the 1972 documentary ''[[Spend it All]]''. Over time they experimented with blending traditional Cajun music with more modern orchestral sounds. They continued together until 1979; that year Rodney and Will died in an [[auto accident]]. In 1980 Dewey's wife died of [[trichinosis]]. Following further lineup changes, the group continued under the name a few years later, and an ensemble continued to perform even after Dewey died in 1992.
The Balfa Brothers together with [[Marc Savoy]] appear playing "Parlez-nous à Boire" towards the end of the 1981 Walter Hill film [[Southern_Comfort_(1981_film)|Southern Comfort]]. Their song "La Danse de Mardi Gras" appears on the soundtracks for the 1992 film ''[[Passion Fish]]'' and the 2012 film ''[[Beasts of the Southern Wild]]''. It also appeared in a commercial for [[Carling Black Label]] Lager.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JgkGjOfkvck</ref>
Two of the Balfa Brothers along with the late Cajun accordionist Danny Poulard are briefly in the movie "Garlic is as good as ten mothers," a 1980 documentary film about garlic directed by Les Blank.

[[David Willetts]] (Work and Pensions){{Collapsed infobox section end}} | birth_name = Theresa Mary Brasier | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|10|1|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Eastbourne]], [[Sussex]], England | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Philip May]]|6 September 1980}} | parents = {{plain list| * Hubert Brasier * Zaidee Mary Barnes }} | residence = [[10 Downing Street]] (official) | alma_mater = [[St Hugh's College, Oxford]] | signature = Signature of Theresa May.svg | website = {{Official URL}} }} {{Theresa May sidebar}} '''Theresa Mary May''' ({{IPAc-en|t|ə|ˈ|r|iː|z|ə}};{{cite web |title=This Is What It's Like To Work In Government For Theresa May |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jamesball/dont-pronounce-her-name-as-tree-za |first=James |last=Ball |authorlink=James Ball (journalist) |work=[[BuzzFeed News]] |date=17 July 2016 |accessdate=6 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906033153/https://www.buzzfeed.com/jamesball/dont-pronounce-her-name-as-tree-za |archivedate=6 September 2017 }} {{nee|'''Brasier'''}}; born 1 October 1956) is a British politician serving as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] and [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Leader]] of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] since [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|2016]]. She served as [[Home Secretary]] from 2010 to 2016. May was first elected [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Maidenhead (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidenhead]] in [[UK general election, 1997|1997]]. Ideologically, she identifies herself as a [[one-nation conservative]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jun/30/theresa-may-sets-out-one-nation-conservative-pitch-for-leadership |title=Theresa May sets out ‘one-nation Conservative’ pitch for leadership|first=Ben|last=Quinn|date=30 June 2016|work=The Guardian|accessdate=24 July 2018}} May grew up in [[Oxfordshire]] and attended [[St Hugh's College, Oxford]]. From 1977 until 1983, she worked for the [[Bank of England]], and from 1985 until 1997 at the [[Association for Payment Clearing Services]], also serving as a councillor for Durnsford in [[London Borough of Merton|Merton]]. After unsuccessful attempts to be elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] in 1992 and 1994, she was elected as the MP for Maidenhead in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]]. From 1999 to 2010, May held a number of roles in the [[Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet (United Kingdom)|Shadow Cabinets]] of [[William Hague]], [[Iain Duncan Smith]], [[Michael Howard]], and [[David Cameron]], including [[Shadow Secretary of State for Transport|Shadow Transport Secretary]] and [[Shadow Secretary of State for Work and Pensions|Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary]]. She was also [[Chairman of the Conservative Party]] from 2002 to 2003. After the [[2010 United Kingdom government formation|formation]] of a [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|coalition government]] following the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]], May was appointed [[Home Secretary]] and [[Minister for Women and Equalities]], giving up the latter role in 2012. Reappointed after the Conservative victory in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], she went on to become the longest-serving Home Secretary in over 60 years. During her tenure she pursued reform of the [[Police Federation of England and Wales|Police Federation]], implemented a harder line on drugs policy including the banning of [[khat]], oversaw the introduction of elected [[Police and Crime Commissioners]], the deportation of [[Abu Qatada]], the creation of the [[National Crime Agency]] and brought in [[Home Office hostile environment policy|additional restrictions on immigration]].{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |last=Rentoul |first=John |work=[[The Independent]] |title=Boring and competent Theresa May is what the nation needs after shock Brexit vote |date=1 July 2016 |accessdate=11 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712173442/http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |archivedate=12 July 2016 }} Following Cameron's resignation, May won a [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|leadership election]] in July 2016, becoming the second female Prime Minister, following [[Margaret Thatcher]]. As Prime Minister, May began the process of [[Brexit|withdrawing the UK from the European Union]], triggering [[Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union|Article 50]] in March 2017 then, the following month, announcing a [[snap election|snap]] [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|general election]] in June, with the aim of strengthening her hand in Brexit negotiations.{{cite news|url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/brexit-secretary-david-davis-resigns|title=Political crises don't come much bigger than Brexit|last=Crace |first=John|date=9 July 2018|work=[[GQ]]|accessdate=10 July 2018|authorlink=John Crace (writer)}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/election-2017-40210957 |title=General election 2017: Why did Theresa May call an election? |date=9 June 2017 |work=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=4 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905062304/http://www.bbc.com/news/election-2017-40210957 |archivedate=5 September 2017 }} This resulted in a [[hung parliament]], in which the number of Conservative seats fell from 330 to 317, despite the party winning their highest vote share [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|since 1983]], prompting her to broker a [[confidence and supply]] [[Conservative–DUP agreement|deal]] with the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) to support a [[minority government]]. May is currently orchestrating the [[Brexit negotiations]] with the [[European Union]], adhering to the [[Chequers Agreement]], agreed in 2018. ==Early life and education== Born on 1 October 1956 in ''The Times'' (London). 11 July 1977. p. 14. ==Early career== Between 1977 and 1983 May worked at the [[Bank of England]], and from 1985 to 1997 as a financial consultant and senior advisor in International Affairs at the [[UK Payments Administration|Association for Payment Clearing Services]].{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2016-07-07/theresa-may-then-and-now-as-she-makes-a-bid-for-prime-minister-we-look-at-her-first-foray-into-westminster/|title=As Theresa May makes a bid for prime minister we look at her first foray into politics|accessdate=9 July 2016|date=7 July 2016|work=ITV News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708125747/http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2016-07-07/theresa-may-then-and-now-as-she-makes-a-bid-for-prime-minister-we-look-at-her-first-foray-into-westminster/|archivedate=8 July 2016}} She married Philip May in September 1980. January 2017}} on the [[London Borough of Merton]] from 1986 to 1994, where she was Chairman of Education (1988–90) and Deputy Group Leader and Housing Spokesman (1992–94). In the [[United Kingdom general election, 1992|1992 general election]] May stood unsuccessfully for the safe Labour seat of [[North West Durham (UK Parliament constituency)|North West Durham]], coming second to incumbent MP [[Hilary Armstrong]] by 12,747 votes (27.6%) to 26,734 (57.8%), with future Liberal Democrat leader [[Tim Farron]] coming third. May then stood at the [[Barking by-election, 1994|1994 Barking by-election]], which was prompted by the death of Labour MP [[Jo Richardson]]. The seat had been continuously held by Labour since it was created in 1945 and Labour candidate [[Margaret Hodge]] was expected to win easily, which she did, with 13,704 votes (72.1%). May came a distant third with 1,976 votes (10.4%). Ahead of the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]], May was selected as the Conservative candidate for [[Maidenhead (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidenhead]], a new seat which was created from parts of the seats of [[Windsor and Maidenhead (UK Parliament constituency)|Windsor and Maidenhead]] and [[Wokingham (UK Parliament constituency)|Wokingham]]. She was elected with 25,344 votes (49.8%), almost double the total of second-placed Andrew Terence Ketteringham of the Liberal Democrats, who took 13,363 votes (26.3%). ==Early political career== Having entered [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]], May became a member of [[William Hague]]'s front-bench [[Her Majesty's Most Loyal Opposition (United Kingdom)|Opposition]] team, as Shadow Spokesman for Schools, Disabled People and Women (1998–1999). She became the first of the 1997 MPs to enter the Shadow Cabinet when in 1999 she was appointed Shadow Education and Employment Secretary. After the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001 election]] the new Conservative leader [[Iain Duncan Smith]] kept her in the Shadow Cabinet, moving her to the Transport portfolio. May was appointed the first female [[Chairman of the Conservative Party]] in July 2002. During her speech at the 2002 Conservative Party Conference, she explained why, in her view, her party must change: "You know what people call us? The [[Nasty Party]]".{{cite book|first=Elizabeth|last=Knowles|title=Oxford Dictionary of Modern Quotations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rjLTsncFKCgC&pg=PA217|date=23 August 2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-920895-1|page=217|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170225212002/https://books.google.com/books?id=rjLTsncFKCgC&pg=PA217|archivedate=25 February 2017}}{{cite book|first=Sarah|last=Childs|title=Women and British Party Politics: Descriptive, Substantive and Symbolic Representation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2yZ-AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT21|date=8 April 2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-21157-9|pages=21–22|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170225212241/https://books.google.com/books?id=2yZ-AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT21|archivedate=25 February 2017}} In 2003, she was sworn of the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Council]] and appointed Shadow [[Secretary of State for Transport]] after [[Michael Howard]]'s election as Conservative Party and Opposition Leader in November that year.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3255441.stm |title=Howard unveils his top team |date=10 November 2003 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=9 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060311034146/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3255441.stm |archivedate=11 March 2006}} In June 2004 she was moved to become [[Shadow Secretary of State for the Family]]. Following the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]] she was also made Shadow [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport]]. [[David Cameron]] appointed her [[Shadow Leader of the House of Commons]] in December 2005 after his accession to the leadership. In January 2009, May was made Shadow [[Secretary of State for Work and Pensions]]. On 6 May 2010, May was re-elected MP for Maidenhead with an increased majority of 16,769{{spaced ndash}}60% of the vote. This followed an earlier failed attempt to unseat her in 2005 as one of the Liberal Democrats' leading "decapitation-strategy" targets.{{cite news ==Home Secretary== {{Main article|Home Office under Theresa May}} [[File:David Cameron's visit2.jpg|thumb|May with her then-leader [[David Cameron]], May 2010]] On 12 May 2010, when May was appointed [[Home Secretary]] and Minister for Women and Equality by Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] as part of his first Cabinet, she became the fourth woman to hold one of the British [[Great Offices of State]], after [[Margaret Thatcher]] ([[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]]), [[Margaret Beckett]] ([[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]]) and [[Jacqui Smith]] (Home Secretary).{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-flies-the-flag-for-women-in-government-1971727.html |title= Theresa May flies the flag for women in Government |work= The Independent |location= London |agency= Press Association |date= 12 May 2010 |accessdate= 16 September 2010 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= Home Secretary, May was also a member of the [[National Security Council (United Kingdom)|National Security Council]].{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107004019/https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/national-security/groups/national-security-council |archivedate=7 November 2014}} She was the longest-serving Home Secretary for over 60 years, since [[James Chuter Ede]] who served over six years and two months from August 1945 to October 1951. May's appointment as Home Secretary was somewhat unexpected, with [[Chris Grayling]] having served as shadow Home Secretary in opposition.{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Nigel|title=Theresa May is surprise choice to be Home Secretary|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-is-surprise-choice-to-be-home-secretary-1972260.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819032255/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-is-surprise-choice-to-be-home-secretary-1972260.html|archivedate=19 August 2016}}{{cite web|title=Cabinet update: Theresa May is surprise Home Sec|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/election-2015/14687/cabinet-update-theresa-may-is-surprise-home-sec|work=The Week|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918150316/http://www.theweek.co.uk/election-2015/14687/cabinet-update-theresa-may-is-surprise-home-sec|archivedate=18 September 2016}} May's debut as Home Secretary involved overturning several of the previous Labour government's measures on data collection and surveillance in England and Wales. By way of a government bill which became the [[Identity Documents Act 2010]], she brought about the abolition of the Labour government's [[Identity Cards Act 2006|National Identity Card]] and database scheme{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/identity-cards-to-be-scrapped-within-100-days-1984447.html |title=Identity cards to be scrapped within 100 days |date=27 May 2010 |work=The Independent |location=London |agency=Press Association |accessdate=28 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100530071415/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/identity-cards-to-be-scrapped-within-100-days-1984447.html |archivedate=30 May 2010}}{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/election_2010/8679072.stm |title=Identity cards set to be scrapped |date=12 May 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=28 October 2010}} and reformed the regulations on the retention of DNA samples for suspects and controls on the use of [[CCTV]] cameras. In May 2010, May announced the adjournment of the deportation to the United States of alleged computer hacker [[Gary McKinnon]].{{cite news |url=http://timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7131780.ece |title=Pentagon hacker Gary McKinnon wins extradition reprieve |last=Sugden |first=Joanna |date=21 May 2010 |work=The Times |accessdate=28 October 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528062652/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7131780.ece |archivedate=28 May 2010}} {{subscription required}} She also suspended the registration scheme for carers of children and vulnerable people, with May saying that the measures were "draconian. Crime Agency]]. In common with the Conservative Party 2010 general election manifesto's flagship proposal for a "[[Big Society]]" based on voluntary action, May also proposed increasing the role of civilian "reservists" for crime control. The reforms were rejected by the Opposition [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]. Following the actions of some members of [[Black Bloc]] in vandalising allegedly [[UK Uncut|tax-avoiding]] shops and businesses on the day of the March 2011 TUC march, the Home Secretary unveiled reforms{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/mar/28/police-new-powers-cuts-protest-home-secretary?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Police may be given new powers after cuts protest, says home secretary |date=28 March 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=1 April 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104093739/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/mar/28/police-new-powers-cuts-protest-home-secretary?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |archivedate=4 November 2013}} curbing the right to protest, including giving police extra powers to remove masked individuals and to police social networking sites to prevent [[Public Order Act 1986|illegal protest]] without police consent or notification.{{cite news|url=http://www.publicservice.co.uk/news_story.asp?id=15918 |title=Police may get social media crime powers |date=29 March 2011 |work=publicservice.co.uk Ltd |accessdate=1 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407025057/http://www.publicservice.co.uk/news_story.asp?id=15918 |archivedate=7 April 2011}} In 2012, despite inquiries by both [[Scotland Yard]] and the [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] ruling that there was no new evidence to warrant further investigation, after discussions with [[Doreen Lawrence|Dame Doreen Lawrence]], May commissioned [[Mark Ellison]] to review Scotland Yard's investigations into alleged police corruption.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/lawrence-murder-police-corruption-will-be-investigated-7811117.html|title=May defies Met to order inquiry after Independent campaign|author=Andrew Grice & Paul Peachey|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=2 June 2012|accessdate=7 March 2014}} The report was presented to Parliament by May on 6 March 2014. [[Bernard Hogan-Howe|Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe]], [[Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police]] said the report, which has prompted an inquiry into undercover policing, was "devastating".{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-26485664|title=Hogan-Howe vows to restore trust in Met after new Lawrence row|publisher=BBC News|date=7 March 2014|accessdate=7 March 2014}} In July 2013, May welcomed the fact that crime had fallen by more than 10% under the coalition government, while still being able to make savings. She said that this was partly due to the government removing red tape and scrapping targets to allow the police to concentrate on crime fighting.{{cite press release |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/crime-is-down-by-more-than-10-under-this-government |title=Crime is down by more than 10% under this government |publisher=Home Office |date=18 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917172845/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/crime-is-down-by-more-than-10-under-this-government |archivedate=17 September 2016}} In 2014, May delivered a speech to the [[Police Federation of England and Wales|Police Federation]], in which she criticised aspects of the culture of the police force.{{cite news |last1=Robinson |first1=Nick |title=May tells police – change or be changed |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27511997 |publisher=BBC News |date=21 May 2014 |accessdate=10 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214033013/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27511997 |archivedate=14 February 2017}} In the speech, she said: {{blockquote|When you remember the list of recent revelations about police misconduct, it is not enough to mouth platitudes about "a few bad apples". The problem might lie with a minority of officers, but it is still a significant problem, and a problem that needs to be addressed ... according to one survey carried out recently, only 42% of black people from a Caribbean background trust the police. That is simply not sustainable ... I will soon publish proposals to strengthen the protections available to whistleblowers in the police. I am creating a new criminal offence of police corruption. And I am determined that the use of stop and search must come down, become more targeted and lead to more arrests.{{cite web|last1=May|first1=Theresa|title=The police must change and so must the Federation|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/home-secretarys-police-federation-2014-speech|website=Gov.uk|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818081359/https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/home-secretarys-police-federation-2014-speech|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}}} On Kingdom|tuition fees]], May praised the actions of the police in controlling the demonstrations but was described by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' as "under growing political pressure" due to her handling of the protests.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/8193115/Royal-car-attack-How-did-the-police-get-it-so-wrong-again.html |title=Royal car attack: How did |title=Police could use water cannon to disperse rioters, Theresa May says |date=12 December 2010 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/8197432/Police-could-use-water-cannon-to-disperse-rioters-Theresa-May-says.html |accessdate=9 August 2011 |deadurl=no 2012}} She rejected their use following the [[2011 England riots|widespread rioting in summer 2011]] and said: "the way we police in Britain is not through use of water cannon. The way we police in Britain is through consent of communities." May said: "I condemn utterly the violence in Tottenham... Such disregard for public safety and property will not be tolerated, and the Metropolitan Police have my full support in restoring order."{{cite news |title= London riots: Police patrol streets after violence |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14435251 |publisher= BBC News |date= 7 August 2011 |accessdate= 9 August 2011 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110809203535/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14435251 |archivedate= 9 August 2011 |df= dmy-all }} In the aftermath of the riots May urged the identification of as many as possible of the young criminals involved. She said: "when I was in Manchester last week, the issue was raised to me about the anonymity of juveniles who are found guilty of crimes of this sort. The Crown Prosecution Service is to order prosecutors to apply for anonymity to be lifted in any youth case they think is in the public interest. The law currently protects the identity of any suspect under the age of 18, even if they are convicted, but it also allows for an application to have such restrictions lifted, if deemed appropriate." May added that "what I've asked for is that CPS guidance should go to prosecutors to say that where possible, they should be asking for the anonymity of juveniles who are found guilty of criminal activity to be lifted".{{cite news |last=Whitehead |first=Tom |date=14 August 2011 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8700761/UK-riots-juveniles-could-be-named-and-shamed-says-Theresa-May.html |title=UK riots: Juveniles could be named and shamed, says Theresa May |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=28 November 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114224855/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8700761/UK-riots-juveniles-could-be-named-and-shamed-says-Theresa-May.html |archivedate=14 November 2013}} ====Anti-social behaviour==== In July 2010, May proposed to review the previous [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] Government's [[anti-social behaviour]] legislation signalling the abolition of the "[[Asbo|Anti-Social Behaviour Order]]" (ASBO). She identified the policy's high level of failure with almost half of ASBOs breached between 2000 and 2008, leading to "fast-track" criminal convictions. May proposed a less punitive, community-based approach to tackling social disorder. May suggested that anti-social behaviour policy "must be turned on its head", reversing the ASBO's role as the flagship crime control policy legislation under Labour.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-10784060 |title=Time to 'move beyond ASBOS' says Home Secretary May |date=28 July 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728185910/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-10784060 |archivedate=28 July 2010}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7914859/Home-Secretary-signals-the-end-of-Asbos.html |title=Home Secretary signals the end of Asbos |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=31 July 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100731090347/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7914859/Home-Secretary-signals-the-end-of-Asbos.html |archivedate=31 July 2010}} Former Labour Home Secretaries [[David Blunkett]] (who introduced ASBOs) and [[Alan Johnson]] expressed their disapproval of the proposals.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/approach-to-antisocial-behaviour-must-be-turned-on-its-head-2037410.html |title=Approach to anti-social behaviour "must be turned on its head" |date=28 July 2010 |work=The Independent |location=London |accessdate=28 July 2010 |first=Wesley |last=Johnson |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730123651/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/approach-to-antisocial-behaviour-must-be-turned-on-its-head-2037410.html |archivedate=30 July 2010}} ====Drug policy==== [[File:Deakhat.jpg|thumb|[[Khat]] bundles]] In July 2013, May decided to ban the stimulant [[khat]], against the advice of the [[Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs]] (ACMD). The council reached the conclusion that there was "insufficient evidence" it caused health problems.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23163017 "Herbal stimulant khat to be banned"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711045838/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23163017 |date=11 July 2013 }}. BBC News. 3 July 2013. Explaining the change in the classification May said: "The decision to bring khat under control is finely balanced and takes into account the expert scientific advice and these broader concerns", and pointed out that the product had already been banned in the majority of other EU member states, as well as most of the G8 countries including Canada and the US.[https://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/may-under-fire-for-banning-khat-8685624.html "May under fire for banning khat".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707042248/http://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/may-under-fire-for-banning-khat-8685624.html |date=7 July 2013 }} ''London Evening Standard''. 3 July 2013. A report on khat use by the ACMD published in January 2013 had noted the product had been associated with "acute psychotic episodes", "chronic liver disease" and family breakdown. However, it concluded that there is no risk of harm for most users, and recommended that khat remain uncontrolled due to lack of evidence for these associations.[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/144120/report-2013.pdf ACMD Report on Khat] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205044630/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/144120/report-2013.pdf |date=5 February 2016 }}. 2013. Liberal Democrat minister [[Norman Baker]] accused May of suppressing proposals to treat rather than prosecute minor drug offenders from a report into drug policy commissioned by the Home Office.{{Cite news |date=27 December 2014 |title=Norman Baker reveals drugs proposals Theresa May stripped from report |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/dec/26/norman-baker-reveals-drugs-proposals-theresa-may-stripped-from-report |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=27 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227044503/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/dec/26/norman-baker-reveals-drugs-proposals-theresa-may-stripped-from-report |archivedate=27 December 2014}}{{Cite news|date=26 December 2014 |title=Ex-minister Norman Baker leaks details on Home Secretary's drug stance |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/exminister-norman-baker-leaks-details-on-home-secretarys-drug-stance-9945643.html |work=The Independent |location=London |accessdate=27 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226183911/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/exminister-norman-baker-leaks-details-on-home-secretarys-drug-stance-9945643.html |archivedate=26 December 2014}} The Home Office denied that its officials had considered this as part of their strategy. ===Immigration=== {{See also|Racism in the UK Conservative Party#Accusations against Theresa May{{!}}Accusations of anti-immigrant racism as Home Secretary}} In 2010, May promised to bring the level of net migration down to less than 100,000.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/oct/06/theresa-may-to-tell-tory-conference-that-mass-migration-threatens-uk-cohesion |title=Theresa May to tell Tory conference that mass migration threatens UK cohesion |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=6 October 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027161451/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/oct/06/theresa-may-to-tell-tory-conference-that-mass-migration-threatens-uk-cohesion |archivedate=27 October 2016}} ''The Independent'' reported in February 2015, "The [[Office for National Statistics]] (ONS) announced a net flow of 298,000 migrants to the UK in the 12 months to September 2014—up from 210,000 in the previous year." In total, 624,000 people [[Modern immigration to the United Kingdom|migrated to the UK]] in the year ending September 2014 and 327,000 left in the same period. Statistics showed "significant increases in migration among both non-EU citizens—up 49,000 to 292,000—and EU citizens, which rose by 43,000 to 251,000."{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/tory-immigration-pledge-failed-spectacularly-as-figures-show-net-migration-nearly-three-times-as-high-as-david-cameron-promised-10071710.html |title=David Cameron immigration pledge 'failed spectacularly' as figures show net migration almost three times as high as Tories promised |date=26 February 2015 |work=The Independent |location=London |first=Andrew |last=Grice |accessdate=20 July 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707150837/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/tory-immigration-pledge-failed-spectacularly-as-figures-show-net-migration-nearly-three-times-as-high-as-david-cameron-promised-10071710.html |archivedate=7 July 2015}} In May 2012 she told the [[Daily Telegraph]] of her intention "to create here in Britain a [[Home Office hostile environment policy|really hostile environment]] for illegal migration,”Kirkup, James (25 May 2012). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/immigration/9291483/Theresa-May-interview-Were-going-to-give-illegal-migrants-a-really-hostile-reception.html "Theresa May interview: 'We’re going to give illegal migrants a really hostile reception’"] – via www.telegraph.co.uk. May rejected the European Union's proposal of [[European migrant crisis#Relocation and resettlement of asylum seekers|compulsory refugee quotas]].Travis, Alan (11 May 2015). [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/11/home-secretary-theresa-may-eu-emergency-resettlement-programme-theresa-may "Home secretary hardens refusal to accept EU resettlement programme"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170127211502/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/11/home-secretary-theresa-may-eu-emergency-resettlement-programme-theresa-may |date=27 January 2017 }}. ''The Guardian'' (London). She said that it was important to help people living in war-zone regions and refugee camps but "not the ones who are strong and rich enough to come to Europe"."[http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/refugee-policy-of-chancellor-merkel-divides-europe-a-1053603.html Mother Angela: Merkel's Refugee Policy Divides Europe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002024728/http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/refugee-policy-of-chancellor-merkel-divides-europe-a-1053603.html |date=2 October 2015 }}". ''[[Der Spiegel]].'' 21 September 2015. In May 2016, ''The Daily Telegraph'' reported that she had tried to save £4m by rejecting an intelligence project to use aircraft surveillance to detect illegal immigrant boats.{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/31/theresa-may-scrapped-aerial-border-surveillance-despite-warnings/ |title= Theresa May scrapped aerial border surveillance despite warnings from former security minister |work= The Daily Telegraph |location= London |last= Dominiczak |first= Peter |date= 31 May 2016 |accessdate= 31 May 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160602103955/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/31/theresa-may-scrapped-aerial-border-surveillance-despite-warnings/ |archivedate= 2 June 2016 |df= dmy-all }} ====Family migration==== In June 2012, Theresa May announced that new restrictions would be introduced to reduce the number of non-[[European Economic Area]] family migrants. The changes were mostly intended to apply to new applicants after 9 July 2012.{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm120611/debtext/120611-0002.htm |title=House of Commons Hansard Debates for 11 Jun 2012 (pt 0002) |publisher=UK Parliament |accessdate=19 October 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020164414/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm120611/debtext/120611-0002.htm |archivedate=20 October 2013}} The newly introduced rules came into effect on 9 July 2012 allowing only those British citizens earning more than £18,600 to bring their spouses or their children to live with them in the UK. This figure would rise significantly in cases where visa applications are also made for children. They also increased the current two-year probationary period for partners to 5 years. The rules also prevent any adult and elderly dependents from settling in the UK unless they can demonstrate that, as a result of age, [[illness]] or [[disability]], they require a level of long-term personal care that can only be provided by a relative in the UK.{{cite web|last=Grower|first=Melanie|title=Changes to Immigration Rules for family members – Commons Library Standard Note SN-06353|url=http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/SN06353|date=18 December 2012|accessdate=6 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130105063524/http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/SN06353|archivedate=5 January 2013}} The [[House of Lords]] was concerned about the immigration issue and therefore addressed the PM in Parliament as to whether she had examined the impact on communities and families on modest incomes, but it received no direct response.{{cite news|last = Mair|first = Lucy|title = Supreme court strikes down Home Office's back-door changes to immigration rules|url = https://www.theguardian.com/law/2012/jul/18/supreme-court-immigration-rules|accessdate = 16 March 2013|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 18 July 2012|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130824180235/http://www.theguardian.com/law/2012/jul/18/supreme-court-immigration-rules|archivedate = 24 August 2013|df = dmy-all}} The human rights group [[Liberty (advocacy group)|Liberty]] concluded that the new rules showed scant regard to the impact they would have on genuine families.{{cite web |title = Liberty's briefing on the Statement of Changes in Immigration Rules |url = http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/pdfs/policy12/liberty-s-briefing-on-the-statement-of-changes-in-immigration-rules-june-201.pdf |first = Yusef |last = Salehi |first2 = Rachel |last2 = Robinson |date = June 2012 |accessdate = 6 January 2014 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121110164239/http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/pdfs/policy12/liberty-s-briefing-on-the-statement-of-changes-in-immigration-rules-june-201.pdf |archivedate = 10 November 2012 |df = dmy-all }} The [[All-Party Parliamentary Group]] on Migration conducted an evidence based inquiry into the impact of the rules and concluded in their report that the rules were causing very young children to be separated from their parents and could exile [[British citizen]]s from the UK.{{cite web|title=Report of the inquiry into new family migration rules|url=http://www.appgmigration.org.uk/sites/default/files/APPG_family_migration_inquiry_report-Jun-2013.pdf|first=Ruth|last=Grove-White|date=June 2013|accessdate=6 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020121731/http://www.appgmigration.org.uk/sites/default/files/APPG_family_migration_inquiry_report-Jun-2013.pdf|archivedate=20 October 2013}} ====Deportation decisions==== [[File:Memorandum of Understanding on transnational crime (5937407114).jpg|thumb|May, David Cameron and [[Najib Razak]], 14 July 2011]] At the Conservative Party Conference in October 2011, while arguing that the Human Rights Act needed to be amended, May gave the example of a foreign national who the Courts ruled was allowed to remain in the UK, "because—and I am not making this up—he had a pet cat". In response, the Royal Courts of Justice issued a statement, denying that this was the reason for the tribunal's decision in that case, and stating that the real reason was that he was in a genuine relationship with a British partner, and owning a pet cat was simply one of many pieces of evidence given to show that the relationship was "genuine". The Home Office had failed to apply its own rules for dealing with unmarried partners of people settled in the UK.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326 |title= Theresa May under fire over deportation cat claim |date= 4 October 2011 |publisher= BBC News |accessdate= 5 October 2011 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111005020900/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326 |archivedate= 5 October 2011 |df= dmy-all }} Amnesty International said May's comments only fuelled "myths and misconceptions" about the Human Rights Act and Justice Secretary [[Kenneth Clarke]] subsequently called May's comments "laughable and childlike."{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Clarke-hits-childish-remarks/story-13490799-detail/story.html |title=Clarke hits out at 'childish remarks' |date=6 October 2011 |work=Nottingham Post |accessdate=14 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008201216/http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Clarke-hits-childish-remarks/story-13490799-detail/story.html |archivedate=8 October 2011}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326|title=Theresa May under fire over deportation cat claim|publisher=BBC News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005020900/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326|archivedate=5 October 2011|date=4 October 2011}} In June 2012, May was found in [[contempt of court]] by Judge Barry Cotter, and stood accused of "totally unacceptable and regrettable behaviour", being said to have shown complete disregard for a legal agreement to free an Algerian from a UK Immigration Detention Centre. As she eventually allowed the prisoner to be freed, May avoided further sanctions including fines or imprisonment.{{cite news [[File:Abu Qatada boards plane.jpg|thumb|Abu Qatada's deportation to Jordan]] On 7 July 2013, [[Abu Qatada]], a radical cleric arrested in 2002, was deported to [[Jordan]] after a decade-long battle that had cost the nation £1.7 million in legal fees,{{cite news |last1=Ttavis |first1=Alan |title=Theresa May criticises human rights convention after Abu Qatada affair |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/08/theresa-may-human-rights-abu-qatada |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=8 July 2013 |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160717201325/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/08/theresa-may-human-rights-abu-qatada |archivedate=17 July 2016}} and numerous prior Home Secretaries had been unable to resolve.{{cite news|title=Abu Qatada deported from UK to stand trial in Jordan|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-23213740|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718082054/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-23213740|archivedate=18 July 2016}} The deportation was the result of a treaty negotiated by May in April 2013, under which Jordan agreed to give Qatada a fair trial, by not using evidence that may have been obtained through torture against him.{{cite news |title=Abu Qatada timeline |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-17769990 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718082058/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-17769990 |archivedate=18 July 2016}} May has frequently pointed to Qatada's deportation as a triumph, guaranteeing in September 2013 that "he will not be returning to the UK", and declaring in her 2016 leadership campaign announcement that she was told that she "couldn't deport Abu Qatada" but that she "flew to Jordan and negotiated the treaty that got him out of Britain for good".{{cite news |last1=Halliday |first1=Josh |title=Abu Qatada will not be allowed back in UK, says Theresa May |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/24/abu-qatada-not-allowed-back-uk-theresa-may-jordan-acquittal-terror |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=24 September 2014 |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160717201355/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/24/abu-qatada-not-allowed-back-uk-theresa-may-jordan-acquittal-terror |archivedate=17 July 2016}}{{cite news |last1=Rentoul |first1=John |title=Boring and competent Theresa May is what the nation needs after the shock of the Brexit vote |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |work=The Independent |location=London |date=1 July 2016 |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701191546/http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |archivedate=1 July 2016}} The Qatada deportation also shaped May's views on the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] and [[European Court of Human Rights]], saying that they had "moved the goalposts" and had a "crazy interpretation of our human rights laws", as a result, May has since campaigned against the institutions, saying that British withdrawal from them should be considered. ===="Go Home" advertisements==== {{main|"Go Home" vans}} {{External media |image1=[https://static.independent.co.uk/s3fs-public/styles/story_large/public/thumbnails/image/2013/07/31/11/immigration.jpg Image of the "Go Home" advert vans]. From ''[[The Independent]]'', Credit: Home Office/PA. |float=right |width=250px}} In August 2013, the Home Office engaged in an advertising campaign directed at illegal immigrants.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/theresa-may-the-new-prime-ministers-5-most-controversial-moments-a7142321.html|title=Theresa May: The new Prime Minister's five most controversial moments|last=Agerholm|first=Harriet|date=18 July 2016|newspaper=The Independent|accessdate=31 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131214148/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/theresa-may-the-new-prime-ministers-5-most-controversial-moments-a7142321.html|archivedate=31 January 2017}} The advertisements, in the form of mobile advertising hoardings on the back of lorries, told illegal immigrants to "go home or face arrest", with an image of a person in handcuffs, and were deployed in six London boroughs with substantial ethnic minority populations. They were widely criticized as creating a [[Home Office hostile environment policy|hostile atmosphere]] for members of ethnic minority groups.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/immigration/10232988/Race-hate-inquiry-into-Home-Office-go-home-billboards.html|title=Race-hate inquiry into Home Office 'go home'
