|df= dmy-all }} ==Prime Minister== {{Main article|Premiership of Theresa May}} ===Leadership election=== {{Further information|Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016}} On 30 June 2016, May announced her candidacy for the leadership of the Conservative Party to replace [[David Cameron]], who resigned following the outcome of the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|European Union membership referendum]] in which 52% of voters voted in favour of leaving the EU. May emphasised the need for unity within the party regardless of positions on leaving the EU, saying she could bring "strong leadership" and a "positive vision" for the country's future. Despite having backed a vote to remain in the EU, she insisted that there would be no second referendum, saying: "The campaign was fought... and the public gave their verdict. There must be no attempts to remain inside the EU, no attempts to rejoin it through the back door... Brexit means Brexit". An opinion poll that day found 47% of people choosing May as their preferred candidate to be Prime Minister.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1719848/theresa-may-is-britons-favourite-for-pm-poll |title=Theresa May Is Britons' Favourite For PM – Poll |last=Carr |first=Harry |date=30 June 2016 |publisher=Sky News |accessdate=2 July 2016 |quote=The other candidates lagged far behind, with Michael Gove on 9% |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702045052/http://news.sky.com/story/1719848/theresa-may-is-britons-favourite-for-pm-poll |archivedate=2 July 2016}} May's supporters included a number of Cabinet ministers, such as [[Amber Rudd]], [[Chris Grayling]], [[Justine Greening]], [[Jeremy Hunt]], [[Michael Fallon]] and [[Patrick McLoughlin]].{{cite news |last=Asthana |first=Anushka |date=1 July 2016 |title=Tory party leadership: support for Theresa May surges as Gove struggles |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/01/support-for-theresa-may-as-tory-party-leader-surges-as-gove-campaign-struggles |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701234700/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/01/support-for-theresa-may-as-tory-party-leader-surges-as-gove-campaign-struggles |archivedate=1 July 2016}} She won the first round of voting on 5 July, receiving support from 165 MPs, with rivals [[Andrea Leadsom]] receiving 66 votes and [[Michael Gove]] 48. After the results were announced, May said she was "pleased" and "grateful" for the support of other MPs and confirmed that she wanted to unite the party and the UK, to negotiate the "best possible deal as we leave the EU", and to "make Britain work for everyone".{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36718196 |title=Tory leadership: Theresa May tops first vote but Liam Fox out |publisher=BBC News |date=6 July 2016 |quote=She added: "I am the only candidate capable of delivering these three things as prime minister, and tonight it is clear that I am also the only one capable of drawing support from the whole of the Conservative Party." |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160705195213/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36718196 |archivedate=5 July 2016}} The two candidates with the fewest votes, [[Liam Fox]] and [[Stephen Crabb]], immediately announced their support for May.{{cite news |last=Asthana |first=Anushka |title=May takes big lead as Fox and Crabb drop out |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/05/theresa-may-conservative-leadership-contest-andrea-leadsom-michael-gove-first-round-vote |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=6 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160706161909/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/05/theresa-may-conservative-leadership-contest-andrea-leadsom-michael-gove-first-round-vote |archivedate=6 July 2016}} May came in first place in the second ballot on 7 July with an overwhelming majority of 199 MPs, compared with 84 for Leadsom and 46 for Gove, who was eliminated.{{cite news |title=Theresa May v Andrea Leadsom to be next prime minister |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36737426 |accessdate=8 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |date=8 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708001014/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36737426 |archivedate=8 July 2016}} Afterwards, May stated that she was delighted with her support among MPs, and she progressed to a vote of the Conservative Party membership against Leadsom.{{cite news |last=Cowburn |first=Ashley |date=7 July 2016 |title=Tory leadership election |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tory-leadership-election-andrea-leadsom-theresa-may-michael-gove-conservative-next-prime-minister-a7125406.html |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |accessdate=7 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708045902/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tory-leadership-election-andrea-leadsom-theresa-may-michael-gove-conservative-next-prime-minister-a7125406.html |archivedate=8 July 2016}} On 11 July, Leadsom announced her withdrawal from the leadership contest hours after May had made her first official campaign speech, saying her lack of support amongst Conservative MPs compared to May would be too great a hindrance to becoming a credible Prime Minister.{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7939901e-4756-11e6-8d68-72e9211e86ab.html |title=May to take over as UK PM by Wednesday |date=11 July 2016 |work=Financial Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712233009/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7939901e-4756-11e6-8d68-72e9211e86ab.html |archivedate=12 July 2016}} As the sole remaining candidate, May was formally declared Leader of the Conservative Party that evening.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |title=Theresa May to succeed Cameron as UK PM on Wednesday |date=13 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=11 July 2016 |quote=The timing of the handover of power from David Cameron looks set to be after PM's questions on Wednesday. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160711161227/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |archivedate=11 July 2016}}{{cite news |date=11 July 2016 |title=Theresa May gives first speech as leader of the Conservative party |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/11/theresa-may-launches-conservative-leadership-bid-as-andrea-leads/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=11 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160711104910/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/11/theresa-may-launches-conservative-leadership-bid-as-andrea-leads/ |archivedate=11 July 2016}} ===Appointment=== On 13 July 2016, two days after becoming Leader of the Conservative Party, May was appointed Prime Minister by [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Queen]] [[Elizabeth II]], becoming only the second female British Prime Minister after [[Margaret Thatcher]], and the first female British Prime Minister of the 21st century.{{cite web|url=https://www.royal.uk/queen-received-audience-right-honourable-theresa-may|title=The Queen received in audience The Right Honourable Theresa May|last=Adam.Vallance|date=12 July 2016|accessdate=17 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818170601/https://www.royal.uk/queen-received-audience-right-honourable-theresa-may|archivedate=18 August 2016}}{{cite news |title= PM-in-waiting Theresa May promises 'a better Britain' |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |accessdate= 18 April 2017 |publisher= BBC News |date= 11 July 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170125064900/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |archivedate= 25 January 2017 |df= dmy-all }}[[List of elected or appointed female heads of government]] Addressing the world's media outside [[10 Downing Street]], May said that she was "honoured and humbled" to become Prime Minister. On becoming Prime Minister, May became the first woman to have held two of the [[Great Offices of State]]. Responding to some calls for an early general election, "sources close to Mrs May" said there was no need for such an election.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36769898 |title=Tributes for David Cameron at his final cabinet as UK PM |author= |date=12 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712112741/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36769898 |archivedate=12 July 2016}} In a speech after her appointment, May emphasised the term "Unionist" in the name of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], reminding all of "the precious, precious bond between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland."{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-36789572 |title=Theresa May: Word unionist 'very important to me' |date=13 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714214126/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-36789572 |archivedate=14 July 2016}} By 15 July, May had travelled to [[Edinburgh]] to meet with [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Nicola Sturgeon]] to reinforce the bond between Scotland and the rest of the United Kingdom. "I'm coming here to show my commitment to preserving this special union that has endured for centuries," she explained.{{cite news |last=Stewart |first=Heather |date=14 July 2016 |title=Theresa May's decisive reshuffle draws line under Cameron era |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/14/theresa-mays-decisive-reshuffle-draws-line-under-cameron-era |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=15 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714203907/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/14/theresa-mays-decisive-reshuffle-draws-line-under-cameron-era |archivedate=14 July 2016}} ===Cabinet changes=== May's first Cabinet appointment was described by [[Reuters]] as "one of the most sweeping government reshuffles for decades", and called "a brutal cull" by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |title=May builds new-look Brexit cabinet to steer EU divorce |last1=Holton |first1=Kate |last2=Pitas |first2=Costas |date=14 July 2016 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=14 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715155255/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |archivedate=15 July 2016}}{{cite news |last=Hughes |first=Laura |date=14 July 2016 |title=Theresa May appoints Justine Greening and Liz Truss after mass cull of old government sees Michael Gove and Nicky Morgan axed |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/14/theresa-mays-cabinet-reshuffle-who-will-join-boris-johnson-and/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=14 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714072212/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/14/theresa-mays-cabinet-reshuffle-who-will-join-boris-johnson-and/ |archivedate=14 July 2016}} Nine of Cameron's ministers, including several prominent members, were sacked or resigned from their posts. The early appointments were interpreted both as an effort to reunite the Conservative Party in the wake of the UK's vote to leave the EU and as "a shift to the right," according to ''[[The Guardian]]''.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/13/theresa-may-becomes-britains-prime-minister |title=Theresa May appeals to centre ground but cabinet tilts to the right |first=Heather |last=Stewart |date=13 July 2016 |work=The Guardian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713235732/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/13/theresa-may-becomes-britains-prime-minister |archivedate=13 July 2016}} ITV's Political Editor [[Robert Peston]] commented: "Her rhetoric is more left-wing than Cameron's was, her cabinet is more right-wing than his was."{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-07-14/may-appoints-right-wing-cabinet-for-left-wing-agenda/ |title=May appoints right wing cabinet for left wing agenda |last=Peston |first=Robert |date=14 July 2016 |publisher=ITV News |accessdate=16 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715155006/http://www.itv.com/news/2016-07-14/may-appoints-right-wing-cabinet-for-left-wing-agenda/ |archivedate=15 July 2016}} Although May had supported remaining in the EU, she appointed several of the most prominent advocates of [[Brexit]] to key Cabinet positions responsible for negotiating the [[United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union]], including [[Boris Johnson]] as [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]], [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]] as [[Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union|Brexit Secretary]], and [[Liam Fox]] as [[Secretary of State for International Trade|International Trade Secretary]], the latter two being new positions.{{Cite newspaper |last1=James |first1=William |last2=MacLellan |first2=Kylie |title=May Builds New-Look Brexit Cabinet to Steer EU Divorce |journal=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |date=15 July 2016 |agency=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=15 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715155255/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |archivedate=15 July 2016}} Other key appointees included [[Amber Rudd]] as [[Home Secretary]] and [[Philip Hammond]] as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]].{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/who-is-david-davis-a-profile-of-britains-new-minister-for-brexit/ |title= Who is David Davis? A profile of Britain's new 'Brexit Secretary' |work= The Daily Telegraph |date= 14 July 2016 |accessdate= 15 July 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160715023920/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/who-is-david-davis-a-profile-of-britains-new-minister-for-brexit/ |archivedate= 15 July 2016 |df= dmy-all }} ===First term=== {{Main article|First May ministry}} [[File:Vladimir Putin and Theresa May (2016-09-04) 02.jpg|thumb|May and [[Vladimir Putin]] during the [[2016 G20 Hangzhou summit|G20 summit]] in [[Hangzhou]]]] [[File:Theresa May speech to UN General Assembly.jpg|thumb|May speaking to the [[United Nations General Assembly]] in September 2016]] The [[First May ministry]] delayed the final approval for the [[Hinkley Point C nuclear power station]] in July 2016, a project which May had objected to when she was Home Secretary.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/29/hinkley-point-c-why-has-government-delayed-final-approval |title= Why have ministers delayed final approval for Hinkley Point C? |work= The Guardian |location= London |date= 29 July 2016 |accessdate= 31 July 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160730205353/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/29/hinkley-point-c-why-has-government-delayed-final-approval |archivedate= 30 July 2016 |df= dmy-all }}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/30/theresa-may-delayed-hinkley-point-chinese-beijing-vince-cable |title=Theresa May 'raised objections to project as home secretary' |work=The Guardian |date=30 July 2016 |accessdate=31 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731203845/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/30/theresa-may-delayed-hinkley-point-chinese-beijing-vince-cable |archivedate=31 July 2016}} Her [[Special advisers (UK government)|political adviser]] [[Nick Timothy]] wrote an article in 2015 to oppose [[China]]'s involvement in sensitive sectors. He said that the government was "selling our [[national security]] to China" without [[rational]] concerns and "the Government seems intent on ignoring the evidence and presumably the advice of the security and intelligence agencies".{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/thecolumnists/2015/10/nick-timothy-the-government-is-selling-our-national-security-to-china.html|title=Nick Timothy: The Government is selling our national security to China|website=[[Conservative Home]]|date=20 October 2015|accessdate=31 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731135519/http://www.conservativehome.com/thecolumnists/2015/10/nick-timothy-the-government-is-selling-our-national-security-to-china.html|archivedate=31 July 2016}} In July 2016, when [[George Kerevan]] asked her whether she would be prepared to authorise the killing of a hundred thousand innocent persons by a nuclear strike; during the "[[Trident nuclear programme|Trident]] debate" inside the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], May said "Yes. And I have to say to the honourable gentleman: the whole point of a deterrent is that our enemies need to know that we would be prepared to use it. Unlike [[Political positions of Jeremy Corbyn#Nuclear defence|some suggestions]] that we could have a nuclear deterrent but not actually be willing to use it, which come from the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] frontbench."{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ODnL6mawWk&t=1173&lc=z12idn3rokrgjnbnh23afzv5dtrafzqj504 |people=Members of the House of Commons |date=18 July 2016 |title= Trident Debate – Theresa May Vs Jeremy Corbyn – UK Parliament – Nuclear Weapons Vote |medium=Video recording |accessdate=18 July 2016 |time=19 minutes and 33 seconds in |location=House of Commons, London |publisher=EU Debate |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119214822/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ODnL6mawWk&t=1173&lc=z12idn3rokrgjnbnh23afzv5dtrafzqj504 |archivedate=19 November 2016}} On 20 July, May attended her first [[Prime Minister's Questions]] since taking office, then afterwards made her first [[List of international prime ministerial trips made by Theresa May|overseas trip as prime minister]], visiting Berlin for talks with German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]]. During the visit, May said that she would not trigger [[UK Invocation of Article 50|Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon]]—the process for withdrawing from the European Union—before 2017, suggesting it would take time for the UK to negotiate a "sensible and orderly departure" from the EU. However, although Merkel said it was right for the UK to "take a moment" before beginning the process, she urged May to provide more clarity on a timetable for negotiations. Shortly before travelling to Berlin, May had also announced that in the wake of the referendum, Britain would relinquish the [[presidency of the Council of the European Union]], which passes between member states every six months on a rotation basis, and that the UK had been scheduled to hold in the second half of 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36841066 benefits.[http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/welfare/2017/03/what-welfare-changes-did-philip-hammond-make-his-budget-2017 What welfare changes did Philip Hammond make in his Budget 2017?] ''[[New Statesman]]'' ===2017 general election=== {{main|United Kingdom general election, 2017}} {{See also|Second May ministry}} On 18 April, May announced that she would call a parliamentary vote to hold an [[Snap election|early general election]] on 8 June, saying that it was the "only way to guarantee certainty and security for years ahead".{{cite news|title=May to seek snap election for 8 June|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39629603|accessdate=18 April 2017|publisher=BBC|date=18 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418101352/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39629603|archivedate=18 April 2017}} May had previously ruled out an early election on five occasions over nine months.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2017/04/five-times-theresa-may-no-10-ruled-snap-general-election/#|title=Five times Theresa May ruled out a snap general election – Coffee House|date=18 April 2017|website=spectator.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418111721/https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2017/04/five-times-theresa-may-no-10-ruled-snap-general-election/|archivedate=18 April 2017}} The election was the first snap election held under the [[Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011]] after MPs gave May the two-thirds [[super-majority]] required.{{cite news|title=General election campaigning begins as MPs back June poll|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39643804|accessdate=19 April 2017|publisher=BBC News|issue=19 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419143625/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39643804|archivedate=19 April 2017}} Unveiling the Conservative manifesto in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] on 18 May, May promised a "mainstream government that would deliver for mainstream Britain".{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39956541|title=Conservative manifesto: Theresa May targets mainstream Britain'|date=18 May 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=18 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170517233142/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39956541|archivedate=17 May 2017}} It proposed to balance the budget by 2025, raise spending on the NHS by £8bn per annum and on schools by £4bn per annum by 2022, remove the ban on new [[grammar school]]s, [[Means-tested benefit|means-test]] the [[Winter Fuel Payment|winter fuel allowance]], replace the [[State Pension (United Kingdom)|state pension]] "triple lock" with a "double lock" and require executive pay to be approved by a vote of shareholders. It dropped the 2015 pledge to not raise income tax or national insurance contributions but maintained a commitment to freeze [[Value-added tax|VAT]]. New [[sovereign wealth fund]]s for infrastructure, rules to prevent foreign takeovers of "critical national infrastructure" and [[Institute of technology|institutes of technology]] were also proposed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/may/18/theresa-may-launches-conservative-manifesto-for-community-and-country|title=May signals break with Thatcherism in manifesto for 'country and community'|last=Mason|first=Rowena|date=18 May 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=18 May 2017|last2=Stewart|first2=Heather|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170518133532/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/may/18/theresa-may-launches-conservative-manifesto-for-community-and-country|archivedate=18 May 2017}} The manifesto was noted for its intervention in industry, lack of tax cuts and increased spending commitments on public services.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39965837|title=Conservative manifesto: Theresa May's 'mainstream' pitch|last=Kuenssberg|first=Laura|date=18 May 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=18 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519222727/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39965837|archivedate=19 May 2017}} On Brexit it committed to leaving the single market and [[European Union Customs Union|customs union]] while seeking a "deep and special partnership" and promised a vote in parliament on the final agreement.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39960311|title=Conservative manifesto summary: Key points at-a-glance|date=18 May 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=18 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170518122902/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39960311|archivedate=18 May 2017}} The manifesto also proposed reforms to [[social care in England]] that would raise the threshold for free care from £23,250 to £100,000 while including property in the means test and permitting deferred payment after death. After attracting substantial media attention, four days after the manifesto launch May stated that the proposed social care reforms would now include an "absolute limit" on costs in contrast to the rejection of a cap in the manifesto.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-40001221|title=General election: Theresa May changes social care plans|date=22 May 2017|work=BBC News|accessdate=22 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170522113910/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-40001221|archivedate=22 May 2017}} She criticised the "fake" portrayal of the policy in recent days by Labour and other critics who had termed it a "dementia tax". [[London Evening Standard|''Evening Standard'']] editor [[George Osborne]] called the policy change a "U-turn".{{Cite news|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-election-care-osborne-idUKKBN18I160|title=May to change social care pledge, George Osborne says|date=22 May 2017|work=Reuters UK|accessdate=22 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170522120119/http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-election-care-osborne-idUKKBN18I160|archivedate=22 May 2017}} ''The Financial Times'' contrasted her "Strong and Stable" leadership slogan with her own record of nine rapid U-turns claiming she was "making a habit of retreating from policies."{{cite web | title=Theresa May's 9 U-turns | website=Financial Times | url=https://www.ft.com/content/e021c208-3ede-11e7-9d56-25f963e998b2 | accessdate=29 May 2017 | last=Mance | first=Henry | date=22 May 2017 | deadurl=no | a hung parliament, prompting her to broker a [[Con–DUP pact|deal]] with [[Northern Ireland]]'s [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP), involving £1 billion of additional public funding for Northern Ireland.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/ng-interactive/2017/jun/08/live-uk-election-results-in-full-2017|title=UK election 2017: full results|work=The Guardian|date=9 June Opening of Parliament, May ordered a full [[public inquiry]] into the [[Contaminated_Blood_Scandal_-_UK|contaminated blood scandal]]{{cite web |title=PM statement on contaminated blood inquiry: 11 July 2017 |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/pm-statement-on-contaminated-blood-inquiry-11-july-2017 |website=GOV.UK |language=en}}. For this she was widely praised as successive governments going back to the 1980s had refused such an inquiry, some though speculated that May had simply been forced to announce the inquiry after a group legal action and news of fresh evidence were brought by Jason Evans.{{cite web |title=Government 'knew risks of contaminated blood months before making it public', son of victim claims |url=http://www.itv.com/news/central/2017-06-22/fight-for-justice-after-dad-given-contaminated-blood/ |website=ITV News |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=Worley |first1=Will |title=New evidence in NHS tainted blood scandal |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/new-evidence-in-nhs-tainted-blood-donation-scandal-28d0qmggs |work=The Times |date=4 July 2017 |language=en}} Additionally, Andy Burnham had threatened to take evidence to the police if an inquiry were not announced{{cite news |title=Contaminated blood scandal: Labour's Burnham threatens to go to police |url=https://news.sky.com/story/contaminated-blood-scandal-labours-burnham-threatens-to-go-to-police-10942488 |work=Sky News}}. With over 1,000 core participants, the [[Infected_Blood_Inquiry|Infected Blood Inquiry]] is the biggest public inquiry ever held in the UK.{{cn|date=October 2018}} [[File:Saudi Arabia massacres civilians in Yemen with U.K. assistance.jpg|thumb|Theresa May came under criticism for providing support to the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]]."[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-39485083 Theresa May defends UK ties with Saudi Arabia]". BBC News. 4 April 2017.]] In November 2017, May said the [[Rohingya persecution in Myanmar (2016–present)|actions]] of [[Myanmar Army]] and police against the [[Rohingya people|Rohingya Muslim]] minority in [[Myanmar]] “looks like ethnic cleansing”."[https://news.sky.com/story/theresa-may-myanmar-must-take-responsibility-for-rohingya-crisis-11125483 Theresa May vows to tackle 'inhuman destruction of Rohingya people']". [[Sky News]]. 14 November 2017. According to May, "it is something for which the Burmese authorities – and especially the military – must take full responsibility." From the 2017 general election to December 2017, May suffered no defeats in whipped votes in the House of Commons.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-brexit-bill-key-amendment-7-dominic-grieve-whips-eu-exit-package-anna-soubry-chuka-a8101636.html|title=Theresa May 'could face first Commons' defeat on Brexit bill next week' on key amendment|date=9 December 2017|work=The Independent|accessdate=30 December 2017}} On 13 December 2017, May lost a vote on the [[EU Withdrawal Bill]] by 309 votes to 305, due to 11 Conservatives voting against the government, including [[Stephen Hammond]] who was then Vice-Chairman of the Conservative Party.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/dec/13/tory-brexit-rebels-inflict-major-defeat-on-theresa-may|title=Tory Brexit rebels inflict major defeat on Theresa May|last1=Stewart|first1=Heather|date=14 December 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=30 December 2017|publisher=|last2=Walker|first2=Peter|last3=Elgot|first3=Jessica}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/stephen-hammond-fired-sacked-brexit-rebellion-tory-mp-theresa-may-latest-a8108691.html|title=The Tories have sacked their own vice-chairman after he helped defeat the Government over Brexit|date=13 December 2017|publisher=|work=The Independent|accessdate=30 December 2017}} May accused [[Russia]] of "threatening the international order", "seeking to weaponise information" and "deploying its state-run media organisations to plant fake stories". She mentioned Russia's meddling in [[German federal election, 2017|German federal election]] in 2017,"[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-russia-election-meddling-warning-cyber-warfare-latest-uk-a8053161.html Theresa May warns Russia over election meddling and vows to protect UK]". ''The Independent.'' 13 November 2017. after German government officials and security experts said there was no Russian interference."[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-election-cyber/germany-sees-no-sign-of-cyber-attack-before-sept-24-election-idUSKCN1BU2KE Germany sees no sign of cyber attack before Sept. 24 election]". Reuters. 19 September 2017. May promised to confront [[China]] on human rights but was praised in [[Communist Party of China|Communist Party]]-controlled [[Media of China|media]] for 'sidestepping' [[human rights in China]] during her first official visit to the country."[http://www.theweek.co.uk/91374/china-applauds-auntie-theresa-may-for-sidestepping-human-rights-issue China applauds ‘Auntie’ Theresa May for sidestepping human rights issue]". ''[[The Week]]''. 2 February 2018. The ''[[Global Times]]'' said: "For the Prime Minister, the losses outweigh the gains if she appeases the British media at the cost of the visit’s friendly atmosphere." In May 2018, during a three-day state visit to the UK by Turkish president [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]], May declared that Britain is a "true friend" of [[Turkey]], but she added that "It is important that in defense of democracy, which has been facing extraordinary pressures from the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|failed coup]], instability across the border from Syria and from [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict (1978–present)|Kurdish terrorism]], Turkey does not lose sight of the values it is seeking to defend."{{cite web|url=http://www.kurdistan24.net/en/news/42566c81-ed95-49fe-b8bd-ec0aae9f8cf3 |title=UK's May uses phrase 'Kurdish terrorism' during Erdogan visit as Kurds protest in London|work=[[Kurdistan 24]]|date= 15 May 2018|accessdate=13 July 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/president-erdogan-theresa-may-post-brexit-trade-turkey-a8351531.html |title=Post-Brexit, the UK will need Turkey for trade – and Erdogan is using that to his advantage|work=The Independent|date= 14 May 2018|accessdate=13 July 2018}} ===Public opinion=== {{Main|Opinion polling for the next United Kingdom general election#Preferred Prime Minister polling}} May had a high approval rating during her first week as Prime Minister. If we were not in Europe, I think there would be firms and companies who would be looking to say, do they need to develop a mainland Europe presence rather than a UK presence? So I think there are definite benefits for us in economic terms.[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/25/exclusive-leaked-recording-shows-what-theresa-may-really-thinks-about-brexit Exclusive: what Theresa May really thinks about Brexit shown in leaked recording] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026091230/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/25/exclusive-leaked-recording-shows-what-theresa-may-really-thinks-about-brexit |date=26 October 2016 }} ''[[The Guardian]]''}} May also said Britain was more secure as part of the [[European Union|EU]] due to the European arrest warrant and Europe-wide information sharing among other factors. She said, "There are definitely things we can do as members of the European Union that I think keep us more safe". [[File:Manchester Brexit protest for Conservative conference, October 1, 2017 17.jpg|thumb|left|Manchester protests ahead of [[Conservative Party (UK) Conference|Conservative Party Conference]] in October 2017]] May's public reticence during the referendum campaign resulted in tensions with David Cameron and his pro-EU team.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/leaked-recordings-reveal-theresa-may-s-pro-eu-stance-ahead-of-brexit-vote-a7380286.html Leaked recordings reveal Theresa May's pro-EU stance ahead of Brexit vote] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171001211444/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/leaked-recordings-reveal-theresa-may-s-pro-eu-stance-ahead-of-brexit-vote-a7380286.html |date=1 October 2017 }} ''[[The Independent]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/uk-pm-may-outlined-brexit-fears-pre-referendum/a-36155785|title=UK PM May outlined Brexit fears pre-referendum |date=26 October 2016|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(http://www.dw.com)|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026234527/http://www.dw.com/en/uk-pm-may-outlined-brexit-fears-pre-referendum/a-36155785|archivedate=26 October 2016}} Following the referendum and her election as party leader, May signalled that she would support full withdrawal from the EU and prioritise immigration controls over remaining within the single market, leading some to contrast this with her earlier remarks on the earlier economic arguments. We have to be prepared to walk out".{{cite news | title=Theresa May prête à un Brexit sans accord | website=Le Figaro |location= Paris |date=29 May 2017 |url= http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2017/05/29/97001-20170529FILWWW00354-theresa-may-prete-a-un-brexit-sans-accord.php |trans-title=Theresa May ready for Brexit without a deal |language=fr |accessdate=29 May 2017 |quote=La Première ministre britannique Theresa May a répété lundi qu'elle était prête à quitter la table des négociations sur le Brexit sans avoir obtenu d'accord avec l'Union européenne si les conditions ne sont pas satisfaisantes pour la Grande-Bretagne. | deadurl=no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170529234210/http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2017/05/29/97001-20170529FILWWW00354-theresa-may-prete-a-un-brexit-sans-accord.php |archivedate=29 May 2017 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite news | title=May says prepared to leave EU without a Brexit deal | website=Reuters UK | date=29 May 2017 |url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-may-idUKKBN18P21R | accessdate=29 May 2017 | deadurl=no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170529214000/http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-may-idUKKBN18P21R |archivedate=29 May 2017 | df=dmy-all }} The [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Lib Dem]] leader, [[Tim Farron]], said it was "disappointing that Theresa May lacked the political courage to warn the public as she did a bunch of bankers in private about the devastating economic effects of Brexit. [[Phil Wilson (British politician)|Phil Wilson]] for the [[Open Britain]] group said, "It's good to know that privately Theresa May thinks what many of us have been saying publicly for a long time, leaving the single market would be bad for businesses and for our economy. Now she is prime minister, Theresa May is in an unrivalled position to act on her previous concerns, starting by putting membership of the single market at the heart of her government's negotiating position." {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=January 2016}} {{Redirect|Urvasi|the song|Kadhalan (soundtrack)}} {{about|character in a Hindu legend|other uses|Urvashi (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox character | image = Urvashi-Pururavas by RRV.jpg | alt = Urvashi | caption = Urvashi and Pururavas painted by [[Raja Ravi Varma]] | children = [[Rishyasringa]] from [[Vibhandaka]]
Ayu from king [[Pururavas]] }} '''Urvashi''' ([[Sanskrit]]: उर्वशी, lit. ''she who can control heart of others. ("Ur" means heart and "vash" means to control'') is an [[Apsara]] ([[nymph]]) in Hindu legend. [[Monier Monier-Williams]] proposes a different etymology in which the name means 'widely pervasive' and suggests that in its first appearances in Vedic texts it is a name for the dawn goddess. She was a celestial maiden in [[Indra]]'s court and was considered the most beautiful of all the Apsaras. She is the mother of [[Rishyasringa]], the great saint of the [[Ramayana]] era of ancient India from [[Vibhandaka]], who later played crucial role in birth of [[Rama]] and was married to [[Shanta]], the elder sister of Rama. She became the wife of king ''[[Pururavas]]'' (''{{IAST|Purūrávas}}'', from ''{{IAST|purū}}''+''{{IAST|rávas}}'' "crying much or loudly"), an ancient chief of the [[Lunar Dynasty|lunar race]]. [[Shatapatha Brahmana|ShBr]] 11.5.1, and treated in [[Kalidasa]]'s drama ''[[Vikramōrvaśīyam]]''. She is perennially youthful and infinitely charming but always elusive.{{cite book | first = K.M. | last = George (ed.) | title = Modern Indian Literature, an Anthology | publisher = [[Sahitya Akademi]] | year = 1992 | isbn = 978-81-7201-324-0 }} She is a source as much of delight as of dolour.{{cite book | first = K.M. | last = George (ed.) | title = Modern Indian Literature, an Anthology | publisher = [[Sahitya Akademi]] | year = 1992 | isbn = 978-81-7201-324-0 }} ==Birth== [[File:Nara Narayana Deogarh.jpg|230px|thumb|Narayana on the left and Nara on the right, [[Deogarh, Uttar Pradesh]], ca. 5th century]] There are many legends about the birth of Urvashi but the following one is most prevalent. Once the revered sages [[Nara-narayana]] were meditating in the holy shrine of [[Badrinath Temple]] situated in the Himalayas. [[Indra]], the king of the Gods, did not want the sage to acquire divine powers through meditation and sent two [[apsara]]s to distract him. The sage struck his thigh and created a woman so beautiful that Indra’s apsaras were left matchless. This was Urvashi, named from ur, the Sanskrit word for thigh. After his meditation was complete the sage gifted Urvashi to Indra, and she occupied the pride of place in [[Indra]]’s court. == See also == *[[Urvashi and Pururavas]] ==References== *''A Dictionary of Hindu Mythology & Religion'' by [[John Dowson]] {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{Hindu apsaras}} {{HinduMythology}} [[Category:Characters in epic poems]] [[Category:Apsara]] [[Category:Characters in the Mahabharata]]
